body: I put thai as the site default with enguk second, and in my admin profile, put enguk as the default then thai second, and the site is rendering in my admin id as thai. switching the site default back to enguk re-renders the site in enguk

I am unable to verify this at the moment. Does this still happen with all other plugins deactivated and all translations updated? Is it limited to these two locales or does it happen with others as well?

Have the same or at least a similar problem here with de_DE_formal as first and de_DE as second.

The7 is only translated for de_DE (not formal) and is using the fallback language english then at their WooCommerce templates. Same goes for another plugin.

Odd that this happens, since the plugin _should_ be bailing early if a plugin like Polylang is already filtering the current locale:

https://github.com/swissspidy/preferred-languages/blob/a11940282f955acc3a58f64d806ef1588f6c093d/inc/functions.php#L352-L355

https://github.com/swissspidy/preferred-languages/blob/a11940282f955acc3a58f64d806ef1588f6c093d/inc/functions.php#L787-L790

I'll try to see whether I can reproduce this with the free version.

I am not able to reproduce this, with the free version at least. **Preferred Languages** **Polylang Languages:** **Posts** (one in each language); **Output** Output of `date_i18n( 'j F Y')` and `get_the_date( 'j F Y')` for each post: * **French**: `9 mars 2021` * **English**: `9 March 2021` * **German**: `9 März 2021` So everything in order there. @markhowellsmead could you try to see if it works for your with the free version?
Closing for now as this is an unconfirmed issue.
I cannot replicate this problem in a clean install with the free version of Polylang.

Hey @swissspidy, could you update me on the status of this PR? :)

> Hey @swissspidy, could you update me on the status of this PR? :)

Thanks for the ping! Don't recall seeing it before as I don't get all the notifications here.

At first glance looks good, but need some actual testing to verify the correct behavior.

Yeah, looks like a dependency issue with phpunit and PHP 7.2. I've been running a patched version of this plugin for a few months now, and it seems to work as intended. Not sure about performance impact (if any), but as far as I can see it should work just fine. 

Seeing as this is opt-in behaviour (see [example code](https://github.com/swissspidy/preferred-languages/pull/315#issue-542159832)), might be okay for the next release?

@swissspidy, can you confirm that the behaviour described in the second scenario does not work? And if so, do you have plans to implement this (if technically possible)?

Thanks!

Hi @tyrann0us, seems like you are actively using the plugin (I've just stumbled upon it due to [this](https://wordpress.org/support/topic/is-this-plugin-compatible-with-wpml-10/)). My current project is still in development and therefore uses the most current WordPress, WooCommerce and WPML versions. Have you encountered any issues with recent plugin versions (if using them)?

Sorry for dropping in out of nowhere 😅
@jwittorf, the plugin works great for us (as in: scenario 1 works). But we don't use WPML, so I can't say anything about it.

Thanks for your quick response! I just gave it a shot, seems to work with WPML :) One needs to disable the "Language Fallback" plugin if it was used before.

I might be getting your "case 7", as I understand that I the behaviour you would be expecting: take the fallback only where needed and use the first priority everywhere else. Since this doesn't seem to be the case: what happens currently in scenario 2?
WordPress uses English (the language used in the source code) for untranslated strings. Basically as if the "Preferred Languages" is not active.

@tyrann0us To answer your questions:

> "Plugin C" has been completely translated to German (Formal) but only partially to German (Swiss)

We need to clarify what "partially" means. Is there a German (Swiss) language pack for "Plugin C" installed on your site or not?

Language packs are usually only generated and downloaded if they are >90% complete.

If you want the German (Swiss) language pack even if it's only 10% complete and thus missing on your site, you'd need to use a plugin like https://wordpress.org/plugins/translation-tools/.

> For "Plugin C", Preferred Languages tells WordPress to fallback to German (Formal) only for the missing translations

This is not currently supported, however is being explored in #41

@swissspidy, thanks for your response.
>We need to clarify what "partially" means. Is there a German (Swiss) language pack for "Plugin C" installed on your site or not?

We use custom client-specific plugins which we translate with Loco Translate. So language packs live in `wp-content/plugins/custom-plugin/languages/` and can be very incomplete (e.g. only 10% translated).

>This is not currently supported, however is being explored in #41

Ah! I totally missed that issue when searching for similar issues. So this is a duplicate.

I just had a look in the log of language pack generation for this plugin.
The first time a language pack was generated for fr_CA was on July 22, 2019. Before that, the translation status was at 94% for a while (i.e. just below the threshold). And some 2 weeks earlier, it was only 3%.

A language pack for a plugin is generated only when at least 95% of the strings in the "Stable plugin" sub project have been transated and also been approved by a translation editor.

When I opened the ticket, it was 100% translated. It still is by the way. 

@tobifjellner Can you confirm what I'm saying?

Well. What I saw was that a language pack for fr_CA was created only on July 22nd. I.e. on July 16 there still was no langpack ready.
Did you translate "Dev" or "Stable"? It's stable that needs to be at 95% or more.

I now had a look at the translation site and can confirm that you indeed finished the translation on July 15 (UTC). Probably some trigger got lost (happens now and then) and no packages were generated, until someone touched some strings for some other language one week later.

This is working now on Multisite:

Ok, seems to be caused by `preferred_languages_update_option()` which is only called when the languages have been changed.
The function calls `preferred_languages_download_language_packs()` for the selected locales but due to the `current_user_can( 'install_languages' )` call it returns false if the current user cannot install languages. As a result the selected locales are lost.

The `current_user_can()` should probably only called if the language isn't installed.

Good catch!

In both cases, `Deutsch (Schweiz)` shouldn't be visible in the `<select>` either, because it's already in the list of preferred locales.
Right, it has the class `hidden` but I guess because it's the first item in the list it will still be displayed.

Thanks for raising this issue! It's an excellent question and I totally understand your use case.

In some way this has been discussed in the past and the conclusion was that an automatic fallback and perhaps merge of languages isn't a good idea.

The usefulness of such a feature essentially boils down to how you're using the list of preferred languages.

When my fallback list is e.g. `es_ES -> de_DE -> en_US`, it would look really weird when half of the UI is in Spanish and the other half in German. And then here and there some English.

However, for `fr_CA -> fr_FR -> en_US` it's not a problem. Ideally, all your UI is in French. If not, some parts will be in English. But that was already the case when just using fr_CA -> en_US.

Perhaps `es_ES -> de_DE -> en_US` isn't the very best example, but I'm sure there will be cases where this could lead to weird results. So it's definitely not a one-size-fits-all solution.

However, for all the other cases where it might make sense, we can surely explore this.

(Of course the easiest solution would be to copy over all fr_FR strings to fr_CA if they haven't been translated already.)

Looking at the code I think this could be achieved programmatically rather easily. I haven't tested it, but https://github.com/swissspidy/preferred-languages/commit/4c78495d46ae4010b19b6d57ec7ba69a4452ef8e is what I had in mind.

I guess you are talking about the WP administration section.

It seems to me like it makes no sense for the website (front-end) to display in Spanish, Deutsch and English at the same time, no ? Maybe I'm missing something.

My suggestion was only for the front-end... but it wasn't clear as I did not mention it.

I was referring to both :-) After all the plugin works on both sides

> It seems to me like it makes no sense for the website (front-end) to display in Spanish, Deutsch and English at the same time, no ? Maybe I'm missing something.
> 
> My suggestion was only for the front-end... but it wasn't clear as I did not mention it.

No I'm not sure I follow 🙂 The two sentences contradict each other. Your suggestion was for the front end but it doesn't make sense?

Let me clarify!

In what case would it make sense to have such fallback:  `es_ES -> de_DE -> en_US` ?

> it would look really weird when half of the UI is in Spanish and the other half in German. And then here and there some English.

It is already going to be weird if plugin A is only translated in es_ES and plugin B is only translated in de_DE. Right ?

Maybe my proposal could be applied only it they all come from the same language.

In the Dashboard, I might prefer `fr_CA -> en_US`as a translator. But on the front-end of the website, I can't see a use case where I'd want the website to be half in fr_CA and half in en_US instead of taking as many strings as possible from fr_CA and filling, for instance, the missing strings with fr_FR or fr_BE.

Is is clearer ?

There could be an option to apply or not the delta. :-)

> In what case would it make sense to have such fallback: `es_ES -> de_DE -> en_US` ?

As I said in https://github.com/swissspidy/preferred-languages/issues/41#issuecomment-428978675, it isn't the best example. I tried to exaggerate to prove a point. A more reasonable problem could be something like `roh -> it -> de_DE -> en_US`. Still the same problem though.

> It is already going to be weird if plugin A is only translated in es_ES and plugin B is only translated in de_DE. Right ?

That's true 🙂 

> There could be an option to apply or not the delta. :-)

Yeah, since this really depends on the context, this couldn't be done automatically for everyone. I'll experiment with adding a filter that one can use if they want this delta to happen in that specific scenario.

Sounds good?
Sounds perfect!

Yeah I just noticed this as well. There's a de_DE translation for the plugin, but it's not loaded. The reason is the just-in-time loading of translations in WordPress. When a plugin doesn't call `load_plugin_textdomain()` themselves (like this one), the fallback mechanism doesn't work. See #22.

Good to know, thanks! What would be a better way to communicate the available keyboard shortcuts?

Honestly I don't know :) The spec recommends exposing the shortcuts to all users:
> Authors should provide a way to expose keyboard shortcuts so that all users may discover them, such as through the use of a tooltip.

However, the introduction of tooltips would probably be a bit controversial, even if TinyMCE is already using them.

I'd consider to add some general info about the new UI in the Help tab at the top of the page, that could include also some info about the shortcuts. It won't completely solve the issue, but could help.

I've initially considered aria-labels, for example:
`<button aria-label="Move down (Alt+ArrowDown)" aria-keyshortcuts="Alt+ArrowDown" ... >Move Down</button>`
but that would be redundant and would defeat the purpose of `aria-keyshortcuts` (when it will be supported). A while ago in an accessibility meeting, we were wondering about the need of a new ["inline help system"](https://wordpress.slack.com/archives/accessibility/p1420678367000781) but that would be definitely out of the scope of this project.

Unrelated:
I'd consider to add audible feedback when locales get added, moved up/down or removed, currently there's no feedback. For inspiration, the customizer already does something similar for menu items and widgets, see for example:
'Menu item moved up'
'Menu item moved down'
'Menu item added'
'Menu item deleted'
'Widget moved up'
etc.
This should go in a separate issue, of course :)

Hi! Thanks so much for spending time on this. The current write package should probably be considered more of a "draft"--lots of tires to kick. It was a known issue (that simplified some internal assumptions) that reading and then immediately writing out DICOMs would not be byte-for-byte equal, but they should be conformant DICOMs. 

One of these assumptions is that we would _always_ write out files in little endian implicit regardless of the input files, which may lead to this issue. 

I think it would be good to work towards byte-for-byte equal, but I think it's a tradeoff between complexity and functionality--writing out an equivalent, fully conformant DICOM is a good first goal.

Will go through this in more detail shortly this week!

Regarding the tests--I agree we should have some flavor of that.

I'm not sure if we need to test bit-for-bit identity yet (I don't think that will pass). We do already have a write test that tests [roundtripping within this library](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/blob/8494b8d69903e329beeff4306605ded5dd702a7a/write_test.go#L28) (e.g. write out a known dataset, and then read it back in and see that it's exactly equal to the original known dataset).

I think a python-linked test that tests we can parse the written dicom by pydicom is certainly a good one. We will have to think about what the best test infrastructure for that would be. (Currently the development setup is very simple and doesn't rely on python, which is nice). One option is to detail the python requirements, and have a helper script setup a python envrironment for running this test (perhaps it should be seperate from the typical go test that runs by default). We should definitly make sure this test always runs on CI, and locally you can specifically go to that test and run it if needed, but may not run as part of `go test ./...` (we could probably also have `make test` run the python setup and run the test if needed).

For the python stuff locally, it would probably be good to run the test in a `virtualenv` so as to not interact with the system python installation. I am pretty wary about adding a hard python dependency for local development, but certainly as a test suite that runs on CI I am good with at the moment

> It was a known issue (that simplified some internal assumptions) that reading and then immediately writing out DICOMs would not be byte-for-byte equal, but they should be conformant DICOMs.

Thanks, that's good context to have. Do you think it would be worth putting that somewhere near the beginning of the README and / or Docs as a warning to developers looking at this lib for DICOM writes? Since the lib is 1.0 some users may find it surprising, but a warning near the beginning on the write feature would make it quick to discover.

> We do already have a write test that tests roundtripping within this library (e.g. write out a known dataset, and then read it back in and see that it's exactly equal to the original known dataset).

Totally, I think it's good to have targeted tests like the ones currently in the write feature, where you know EXACTLY what values are involved.

I also think it's worth while to have a round-trip test of non-synthesized data, where we pull in a number of *full* DICOMS with real-world data and make sure every element in them is correctly read, written, and read again. That was what let me find #199 and #193. And the tests as-written would be easy to expand to larger test datasets, should we want. Further down, I discuss using build tags for some, more complicated tests. So maybe we could add an `integration` tag for these tests so they are not run by default, but are still run on CI or when a developer wants to run the full test suite.

> I think it would be good to work towards byte-for-byte equal, but I think it's a tradeoff between complexity and functionality--writing out an equivalent, fully conformant DICOM is a good first goal.

Agreed completely. 

> I'm not sure if we need to test bit-for-bit identity yet (I don't think that will pass). 

Also agreed, although we could always call t.Skip() on it for now and leave it in as an aspirational test if bit-for-bit parse / write is something you would like to strive for *in general* in the future, anyone working towards that goal then has a pre-wrritten set of tests they can re-enable if they so desire.

> We should definitly make sure this test always runs on CI, and locally you can specifically go to that test and run it if needed, but may not run as part of go test ./... (we could probably also have make test run the python setup and run the test if needed).

I think this a natural use case for [build tags](https://mickey.dev/posts/go-build-tags-testing/), IMO. That way by default, developers don't have to worry themselves with setting up python unless they want to, while requiring minimal scripting on our part. We could have a `validation` build tag, and maybe also have a `bytes_symmetry` tag for the bit-for-but tests instead of using t.Skip().

Then we could have `make test` run the basic tests using the current test command and maybe `make tests-validation` run
`go test ./... -v -tags=validation` and `make test-future` run `go test ./... tags=bytes_symmetry` or something like that. I've also been looking into other third-party dicom validation tools, so we could add other tests as well that call other third-party validation tools.

> For the python stuff locally, it would probably be good to run the test in a virtualenv so as to not interact with the system python installation. 

IMO, this is a choice we should leave to the developer. I use `python -m venv` to setup my virtual environments, but some people use [pyenv](https://github.com/pyenv/pyenv), and still others use [poetry](https://python-poetry.org/). I think having a `python_requirements.txt` file and an explanation in the readme is probably enough to let anyone who wants to run those tests locally to run them without having to do too much setup, and for CI I don't think there's much of a problem using the system Python.

I'll open a couple draft PR's for the tings discussed here, and we can maybe discuss the pros and cons of the individual elements there and close this issue.

Hi! Thanks for raising the issue and for posting a great minimal example. I agree that this is something we should address, particularly since that Go routine holds a reference to the read dataset (so the dataset presumably isn't cleaned up during GC even when it's not needed).

Semantically, I think using a context is reasonable though it's easy for the caller to mess up which I'm not a big fan of (e.g. if the caller just passes context.Background()).

While I like the channel semantics here, another option is to implement a stateful iterator object that doesn't run inside a goroutine (though it'll be a bit more work, and we'd have to think about what happens if the dataset object changes under the hood in another Go routine, though that can be explicitly out of scope). When that iterator object doesn't have any more references, it'll be destroyed as usual. 

By stateful iterator I mean something like
```
iter := dicom.FlatIterator(dataset)
for iter.HasNext() {
    val := iter.NextValue()
}
```

I could envision a pretty straightforward implementation, even if the dataset ends up mutating in the middle of the FlatIterator (though if we want we can call that out). 

I think I will prototype a stateful iterator approach just to see, as I think it would be more difficult for the caller to accidentally use incorrectly vs the context approach. Let me know if you have any thoughts on this!

I think your first instinct of moving to a stateful iterator is the better approach, personally. Implementing a Closer adds to the amount of bookkeeping the caller needs to keep track of, and will likely be confusing to a caller as we aren't really connecting to any sort of external resource, same with my suggestion of a context. 

Whereas with a stateful iterator you can just let it go out of scope and the garbage collector will do its thing as normal. It's also a familiar pattern, both the builtin sql lib and the mongoDB driver use the iterator approach for cursors, which to me indicates it's the more idiomatic approach.

 If you're open to a total redo of the method, then an iterator seems like the way to go to me.

I considered this as well, however one consideration is that this gives the caller a static flattened copy of element pointers. It's possible if the underlying data set changes that this flattened copy is out of sync. Luckily if any of the individual elements change its fine (as we're holding pointers), but not if elements are added or removed. Perhaps it should be common sense for the caller to watch out for situations like this (and perhaps those cases would be uncommon). 

in any case, a stateful iterator seems to be the most natural approach--doesn't suffer from the problem above, it's easily garbage collected, though the API is slightly more complex (e.g. can't just range over the return value sadly).

To unblock, perhaps I can go ahead and implement a simple stateful iterator that builds the Flattened() set of element pointers and then returns elements over it (as opposed to a possibly more complex implementation). If we wanted, we could consider exposing the underlying Flatten() operation as well with a note that it is a static snapshot of the Dataset. The iterator API could remain the same, but there are several future optimizations we could do--for example, don't recompute the flattened dataset if the underlying dataset hasn't changed (e.g. cache it), etc. But API wise, getting folks to use the iterator seems reasonable to me. Thoughts?

I've put up a draft in #184. I've added `FlatStatefulIterator` and added an ExhaustElementChannel that can be used to exhaust the channel in a defer for the channel-based API. I think we should consider deprecating the channel API, but it is in use today, and some consumer depend on the channel (e.g. having multiple processing goroutines read elements off of the channel). Most of those existing consumers aren't affected by this issue, as they exhaust the channel regardless of an error in processing any given element. Likely would want to evaluate those use cases and deprecate the API release after next to ease the transition off of it.

At some point either we should deprecate the channel-based API, or we should rename it so that it's not seen as the default for iteration (e.g. name it FlatChannelIterator or something). For most usecases, the stateful iterator should be sufficient, but having the channel approach around may still be useful for some users.

I think it makes sense to deprecate the channel version over time. I feel like concurrency-awareness might make sense to leave up to the caller, and be considered out-of-scope for the lib. Callers can implement distributing the results of the iterator over a channel, locking the dataset for read / writes, etc.
Also let me know if I can help in anyway! (code review, etc)

yeah, as said before I think deprecation makes sense, though I think it would be nice to phase it out over the next 2 releases as mentioned above. I may also add some benchmarks to do some comparisons, but copying a bunch of pointers shouldn't be a big deal.

> Thanks for the updates! A couple more comments, but I think we're getting very close!
> 
> re: the name formatting, I think if we print out a description of what is printed along with the name (e.g. a key) that should be sufficient for internationalization, something like
> 
> `"Mr. John Bob Smith III [NamePrefix, GivenName, MiddleName, FamilyName, NameSuffix]"`
> 
> This way, it is clear to the reader what each component printed means. Typically I expect the major usage of String() to be in debug logs or something like that.

`"Mr. John Bob Smith III [NamePrefix, GivenName, MiddleName, FamilyName, NameSuffix]"`

... could result in something like: 

`"Mr. John  Smith III [NamePrefix, GivenName, MiddleName, FamilyName, NameSuffix]"`,

Which makes it kind of hard to figure out which field is missing. We could also result in something like:

`"Mr. John Smith III [NamePrefix, GivenName, FamilyName, NameSuffix]"`

Where we remove the missing fields, but that also hides from the caller that there are fields missing. We could also do something like:

`"[NamePrefix='Mr.' GivenName='John' MiddleName='Bob' FamilyName='Smith' NameSuffix='III']"`

But at that point, we are kind of just implementing our own formatter '%+v' directive, which would spit out:

`{FamilyName:Potter GivenName:Harry MiddleName: NamePrefix: NameSuffix: NoNullSeparators:false}`

... and I'm left wondering if it just makes sense to leave calling '%+v' in fmt.Printf / Sprintf to the user for debugging.

It's worth noting that by implementing fmt.Stringer, you take away the ability for the caller to use %+v on the struct (both %v and %+v will return the result of the String() method). For a type like big.Rat -- which is modeling a singular value like a fraction -- where the individual fields are implementation details, this makes sense.

But at the end of the day the personname.GroupInfo type is just a container for a bunch of labeled data, and is exactly the type of value the built-in formatting directives are intended to support, so I don't know that we gain much by implementing our own String() even on the debugging front: The developer is just going to get a kind of unexpected result when using fmt.Printf("%+v\n", groupInfo).

Just pushed a new version, some of your questions prompted me to reflect a little more on the API and some edge cases I had not considered. Sorry to be making changes like this when we are close to a merge, but I think the API will be better for it.

Here's a quick summary of the updates:

### Changed 'NoNullSeparators' fields to 'TrailingNulls' fields

I tend to like having values be "safe by default", and when originally designing this API, I figured including null separators was the "safer" option than omitting them when rendering a PN value. Since the default bool value is false, that means the null separator field needed to be NoNullSeparators, where false means there *are* null separators.

However, I think having a double negative is semantically kind of annoying, and makes reasoning about formatting less intuitive than it could be, so I opted to change the field to TrailingNulls, where a true value means null separators were present / will be rendered. I've inverted all the values in the tests / examples. I think this makes the setting more scrutable and explicit, especially for passing arguments to the added WithFormat() method below.

Other method names have been altered to reflect this field name change.

### Added WithFormat() method

This method adds more granularity than the WithNullSeparators and WithoutNullSeparators methods do on their own. It can be used like so:

```
func ExampleInfo_WithFormat() {
	rawVal := "Potter^Harry^^^=^^^^=^^^^"

	parsedPN, err := personname.Parse(rawVal)
	if err != nil {
		panic(err)
	}

	fmt.Println("ORIGINAL   :", parsedPN.DCM())

	reformatted := parsedPN.WithFormat(
		false, // groupTrailingNulls
		// We will keep empty separators for the Alphabetic group.
		true,  // alphabeticTrailingNulls
		false, // ideographicTrailingNulls
		false, // phoneticTrailingNulls
	)
	fmt.Println("REFORMATTED:", reformatted.DCM())

	// Output:
	// ORIGINAL   : Potter^Harry^^^=^^^^=^^^^
	// REFORMATTED: Potter^Harry^^^
}
```

### Added WithoutEmptyGroups() method

A formatting method that flips Info.TrailingNulls to false, and then examines each group, and if it has no actual information, sets its TrailingNulls setting to false. This is useful for rendering a PN value with all trailing nulls if there is _any_ information in a group, but eliding groups that have no information.

```
func ExampleInfo_WithoutEmptyGroups() {
	rawVal := "Potter^Harry^^^=^^^^=^^^^"

	parsedPN, err := personname.Parse(rawVal)
	if err != nil {
		panic(err)
	}

	fmt.Println("ORIGINAL   :", parsedPN.DCM())

	reformatted := parsedPN.WithoutEmptyGroups()
	fmt.Println("REFORMATTED:", reformatted.DCM())

	// Output:
	// ORIGINAL   : Potter^Harry^^^=^^^^=^^^^
	// REFORMATTED: Potter^Harry^^^
}
```

### Edge case considerations

When going through your final notes, I realized there was an edge case I had not considered:

The value `"Potter^Harry^"` is technically a legal PN value. It has _some_ tailing nulls but not a full set of trailing nulls. Such a value cannot currently be round-tripped with the current implementation / API. The DCM() method would render back out
`"Potter^Harry^^^"`

My first instinct was that this is probably okay, as a non-full set of trailing nulls getting reformatted into a full set isn't so bad. But this passage of the DICOM spec, which specifies PN values for use in Veterinary settings has me reconsidering that stance:

> For veterinary use, the first two of the five components in their order of occurrence are: responsible party family name or responsible organization name, patient name. The remaining components are not used and shall not be present.

Which leads me to believe that a PN value like:

`'PEAKE^NELLY==PEEK^'` might be a valid and useful representation, where the last group has a known pronunciation for the owner's last name, but not the pet's name, and such a value when round-tripped would get reformatted to `'PEAKE^NELLY==PEEK^^^'`. This could cause unexpected issues if a vet clinic were, say, updating a pet's name or something similar.

I know that is an ultra niche edge case, but I would like to do my best to FULLY capture the DICOM spec here, and I think maybe there should be some way to specify the LastNullSep value or something similar, so we can fully capture what is allowed by the DICOM spec, might be really useful. I think I am going to work on one final update to handle that, so you may want to hold off on a final final review until that is done.

Thanks again for being so thorough in these reviews, the DICOM spec is filled with so many of these non-obvious gotchas, and your questions have really helped me to think about whether this covers ALL the possibilities that it allows.

Just pushed a change that tracks how many null separators there were on parse / should be on write.

I'm still going back and forth on whether separator level is actually part of the legal DICOM spec, it is not specifically addressed, stating simply:

> Trailing null components and their delimiters may be omitted.

But not clarifying whether trailing null components must ALL be omitted or retained. This latest update allows the round-tripping of a value like `"Potter^Harry^"`, and I think it's probably best to allow for that possibility, especially given the veterinary use case where `"Potter^"` makes some sense for a known animal owner, but an unknown animal name.

Still, let me know what you think. Rather than detailing the API changes here, I would say take a look at the code examples.

Here are the example PN values from the DICOM spec for your reference. It does not include an example like what I am accounting for here, but neither does it specifically exclude it:

> Rev. John Robert Quincy Adams, B.A. M.Div.
> 
> "Adams^John Robert Quincy^^Rev.^B.A. M.Div."
> 
> [One family name; three given names; no middle name; one prefix; two suffixes.]
> 
> Susan Morrison-Jones, Ph.D., Chief Executive Officer
> 
> "Morrison-Jones^Susan^^^Ph.D., Chief Executive Officer"
> 
> [Two family names; one given name; no middle name; no prefix; two suffixes.]
> 
> John Doe
> 
> "Doe^John"
> 
> [One family name; one given name; no middle name, prefix, or suffix. Delimiters have been omitted for the three trailing null components.]
> 
> (for examples of the encoding of Person Names using multi-byte character sets see Annex H)
> 
> "Smith^Fluffy"
> 
> [A cat, rather than a human, whose responsible party family name is Smith, and whose own name is Fluffy]
> 
> "ABC Farms^Running on Water"
> 
> [A horse whose responsible organization is named ABC Farms, and whose name is "Running On Water"]

I think where I have landed on this is it's probably best to stay on the safer side and allow for this use case. If you would prefer to go back to using presence-only, we can roll back to  commit 1b46044

Regarding the edge cases you mention--I will take a closer look this weekend and we can decide how to handle it. I think it's reasonable to have some TODO items and known bugs/feature requests to address in future PRs.

Yes, this is a known behavior (see #2 for autoscale of pixel values issue). The reason it is done as it is now is to preserve the clinical data in the PixelData (which often times map to actual measurements like Hounsfield units). This currently allows to caller to rescale as appropriate for their context.

For example, imagine a caller that is a image viewer. The user will input/change some value of window width and window center, that should be used in the rescaling formula that applies to the _original_ values in the pixel data, so could be applied directly to the image.Image as is today.

100% agree we should offer a default option for rescaling the pixel values based on the current values of various relevant tags (e.g. rescale intercept and slope, etc), but I think that should potentially be a set of utilities in a utility package (maybe `pkg/imgutil` or `pkg/frameutil`?) that helps with the rescaling. If the user applies a flag to the `dicomutil` utility, we can invoke some of this autoscaling. 

Also of course this currently applies to NativePixelData, though rescaling based on formulas and selections of window width and window center may also apply.

#157 led to some significant performance improvements by reducing slice allocations.

Also, on this subject, @kaxap has observed that eliminating calls to `binary.Read` may reduce slice allocations and improve performance a bit, so that's something we should try. In particular, doing something like the following to read uint8, uint16, uint32s, etc:

```go
buf := make([]byte, bitsAllocated/8)
for pixel := 0; pixel < pixelsPerFrame*samplesPerPixel; pixel++ {
  _ := io.ReadFull(d, buf)
  val := int(binary.LittleEndian.Uint16(buf))
}
```

The main advantage here is reusing the buffer slice (since bitsAllocated should be constant), instead of binary.Read creating one within.
it is also possible to lazily load frames from file which will result in smaller memory footprint (some dicom files can be gigabytes in size)

This is somewhat along the lines of #162--which is allowing interested parties to not read the pixel data, or perhaps, to pause reading before actually parsing the PixelData (which can be done with the Parser API, but not at the frame by frame level, but at the tag by tag level). We can also read in the bytes and do nothing with unpacking them until a user wants the image.Image, which is _almost_ what we do today. I'm leaning towards something similar to current behavior + an option to not read PixelData (or any blocklist of tags potentially). We also already have a "streaming" option where frames can be consumed by a consumer as they are parsed, instead of having to wait for the full set of frames (or the whole dicom) to be parsed. 

What do you think? Also, would love to learn more about your use cases if you have any particular ones. Cheers!

Most of the cases all I want to do is to get some tags and a single frame rendered (for a thumbnail or a preview). Lazy mode (when we save offsets in file for each frame instead of reading all of them into RAM) looks very appealing in this case.
@suyashkumar could you please take a look on this [fork](https://github.com/kaxap/dicom)? We're seeing 5-10x speed improvements due to reduced hot path allocations.

hi @kaxap, thanks for reaching out, looks like we are both pulling at the same thread here!

Note that there will be a larger apparent percent latency reduction for files with more frames or larger frames (don't have such examples in `testdata/` yet, so it's not as apparent in the benchmarks above).

Similar to your implementation, this change removes an unnecessary slice allocation in the loop. In this implementation, two slices are allocated per frame in advance of parsing the frame. In your implementation, I see you read the data into a single dimension slice until the user wants to unpack it (where the rest of the work is done). This is something I considered myself, however I was able to achieve similar results without changing the API surface (in the struct) in this change so I prefer that until the next minor release with api breaking changes. The reason for this is because slicing a golang slice doesn't lead to copying (though there is still some minor overhead).

One of the things I see in your implementation is replacing the calls to `binary.Read`, which seems very interesting and useful--I didn't know it allocated a slice under the hood!

Would you be able to run the benchmarks on your fork so we can see how they look? And/or, would you be willing to open a PR here with the uint read changes to move away from `binary.Read` (but we can keep the slice structure the same for now)? If you open a PR, it will automatically run the benchmarks as a GitHub action and compare to baseline. Alternatively, I can make a change to that effect and add you as a co-author.

I will probably go ahead and merge this change to separate it from the others (there are some others I'd like to make too).

Hi there! Thanks for the suggestion, I think it's a good idea to help folks work with native Go dates and durations.

I'd like to think a little about where this should live. I'm wondering if maybe this should be inside a utility subpackage (something like `pkg/dcmtime`) since the top level library API is already becoming somewhat complicated, and I'd like to simplify. Also, this logic may be useful for folks working with dicom date strings that may not come directly out of a dicom (e.g. maybe from some third party place like Google cloud dicom store). 

The other option is to treat Date Strings as special ValueTypes during parsing, and parse them directly into native Go containers. Because without generics this is a little cumbersome, I'm somewhat partial to maybe avoiding too many additional ValueTypes if possible.

I'm leaning towards a `dcmtime` package with a different API, perhaps something like:

```go
// FromDateString converts a DICOM date string (from VR=DT or VR=DA) to a Go time.Time.
FromDateString(dateStr string) (time.Time, error)

// FromAgeString ...
FromAgeString(ageStr string) (time.Duration, error)
```
Agree, looks better to keep only Go base types in default package and move time.Time, time.Duration, etc.. in an extension.

Thanks for the suggestion and the kind words! I've been thinking about putting something like this on the roadmap (maybe more offering a dicomWEB client and/or server package that work well with this library). 

If possible, can you share a little more info about both of your usecases, and what functionality in particular you would find most valuable?

Of course, as you know the DICOM standard does not only specify a file format but also a network protocol.

The latter is used, for example, by all medical imaging devices (modalities), PACs, viewers, analysis consoles, etc. to communicate with each other.

The WEB version (DICOMWeb / WADO) has been emerging for a few years mainly for Web usage (as its name indicates), but 99% of medical data exchanges still use the old DICOM UL protocol.

Today, mainly two Open source libraries implement it: DCMTK (C++) and DCM4CHE (Java). 
They are both of a certain age (20 years old for DCM4CHE, 24 years old for DCMTK), their maintenance and documentation is becoming more and more difficult, and I think there is room for a new generation of OpenSource libraries covering the entire standard.

It would allow the emergence of a new generation of medical software, more modern, more secure, more "Cloud native" and the Go language is perfect for that.

With the advent of digitized patient records, AI, graph oriented databases, and access to healthcare for the largest number of people, it may be time to dust off the DICOM environment.

I can provide some of my time for contribution.

I think approach 2 should suffice though.

@suyashkumar I went ahead and implemented the fixes we discussed and we have definitely made progress. It seems that this fix partially works. For files that are broken in the missing 'DICM' keyword, it appears that we can now read the data contained in them (as tested with the files I have available, see [issue 59](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/issues/59), comparing it to fields outputted by dcmtk and pydicom).

However, when attempting to read files that aren't broken in this way, the program is unable to parse the file and gives an errors in the format of those in [issue 63](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/issues/63) (e.g. `ERROR Trying to read 66096 bytes beyond buffer end (file offset 146) 51-103.dcm`

I haven't had a chance to look into this error yet to see if it's easily fixable, but if not, I suspect that we could pretty easily implement a check to call `NewParser()` if 'DICM' is at byte 128 even if the force flag is set to true. That way, if [issue 63](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/issues/63) is a pain to fix, we can worry about fixing it later and still get this feature out.

Let me know what you think or if you have any other ideas/comments/feedback/changes to make.

> Thanks @IChocked! Added some inline comments. In general, it's possible the issue you're getting is due to the default choice of transfer syntax as mentioned, but most likely it's due to garbage being present in the first 128 bytes + 4 bytes that the parser is attempting to parse as valid tags--this could cause some alignment issues with the actual data downstream.
> 
> One semi-hacky way to avoid this is to discard any tag that doesn't look like a tag while in forced mode. I don't really like this though. I'll think on it some more in the morning to see if we can come up with a more graceful solution here. Maybe having it be a clear part of the API (maybe by renaming it to NewParserWithoutMetadata or something) would make the current behavior okay, but I don't like it very much just yet.
> 
> I think in the 1.0 api, being have to pass in a SkipMetadata option may make this a lot cleaner. Have you had a chance to play around with the 1.0 API/parser at all (no worries if not, just curious)!

Thanks for all the feedback! 

Have you had a chance to think more about a better way of solving this issue? The only additional way I was able to come up with is very hacky and is to create a temporary parser within the `NewParserForce()` function and parse the file header as if the file were valid, then if `temp_parser.parsedElements` contains valid elements, set actual `p.parsedElements` to contain them and set `p.decoder` to where `temp_parser` left off. And for safety, `temp_parser` would end if it receives a tag after `(0002,0102)`, which is the last possible tag in the header, or if MetaElementGroupLength is defined in the file, or if the position of `temp_parser.decoder` exceeds the maximum possible length of the file header. And if `temp_parser` failed to get any useful information, it would be assumed that the file is missing a header and thus could be read by just skipping the header and using default transfer syntax.

I haven't had a chance to start experimenting with 1.0 yet, but I believe my next project after this is to start playing with it and testing our code with it, so I should have some feedback/results sometime soon hopefully!

@wkoszek possibly some more work is required--namely to fix the `Read x Bytes Beyond Buffer End` encountered (see the discussion above). 

Reminding myself of the issue here it seems like when trying to pass "correct" DICOMs through the parser with force enabled, it fails--which is not surprising, because this implementation doesn't skip over the 128+4, and so the parser offset is incorrect.

However, with the force disabled everything works as expected.

@IChocked is this a correct summary of the issue?

Maybe this could be considered a feature and not a bug, as sorta mentioned above maybe we should rename this `NewParserAssumeNoPreamble` or something to indicate this creates a parser that will _only_ work on DICMs with no preamble (128+4bytes), and that it will __not function correctly__ and have undefined behavior for DICMs that _do_ have the preamble.

I'm not a huge fan of this approach, but I think it will solve your problem. I can write a version of this for 1.0 that takes in an option instead to `AssumeNoPreamble()`.

Another option is to be more intelligent about this, so that we can intelligently "fall back" to this behavior, but I think this is sufficient if it will unblock y'all for now. You will have to write logic in the calling program to try to parse the dicom normally, and if it fails, then attempt with the force option.

@suyashkumar @wkoszek It's been a while, but I think another caveat to this was that almost any files that are missing the preamble are also missing the MetaElementGroupLength tag and thus invoke [issue #53](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/issues/53) (at least the ones that we came across at [Segmed](https://www.segmed.ai)), so having the force flag wasn't much benefit unless we can also fix #53 which was where we left off

@IChocked if we are skipping the explicit metadata parsing in this PR, I don't think we'll run into the `MetaElementGroupLength` check right? We'll just end up blindly parsing a dataset in LittleEndian explicit (unless we run into a transfer syntax tag, at which point we'll switch over to that)?

Again, we're in uncharted territory here, because these DICOMs do not adhere to the spec.

Hm. DCMTK has it somehow figured out, so that even DICOMs an be processed.

I guess in the worst case, for those broken files, we could use DCMTK to fix the DICOMs first, and then re-ingest them.

If there really isn't a safe way to support this PR, let's close it. Our CLI will have to be taught to spin a DCMTK, read the unbroken DICOM back, and use Golang DICOM library to re-read them.

I think we can support it similar to how it this PR is now, it just may require two passes by the caller. e.g. you would try to parse the dicom normally, and if that doesn't work, you would retry with the force option (which I don't think is the worst).

I can also probably put together a way to support this inline in the rewritten version, we would just need to store a little side buffer so we can rewind (or peek ahead) to do the DICM check. 

I can try to prototype something this weekend to that effect, or we can clean up this PR as noted above (e.g. let's rename `NewParserForce` to `NewParserAssumeNoPreamble`). Assuming that my assumption above about not invoking the metadata check is correct (let me know if I missed something @IChocked)

Hi there @bbeckrest! I can take a deeper look later this weekend if needed, but one thing that may be worth trying is index `1` for the frame, which should index into the second pixeldata value.

What happens if you try:
`slice.pixelData.Frames[1].GetImage()` in your code instead of `slice.pixelData.Frames[0].GetImage() `?

@suyashkumar Thanks for the reply. 

Trying the suggestion above causes a panic due to `Frames` only having a length of 1. Not sure why it's not parsing the second pixeldata value.

```go
runtime error: index out of range [1] with length 1
```

@bbeckrest apologies for the delay! Looks like this issue is coming from the jpeg.Decode call (from [here](https://github.com/golang/go/blob/c5ac91d0e1082914d3eeb8dff9d80974eb1bf9b7/src/image/jpeg/reader.go#L647)). One option is to take the encapsulated pixel byte data and write out the byte data to disk to see if you can open it in a jpeg tool of your choice. Taking a look, there does seem to be data in the `EncapsulatedFrame`.

You'd want to try something like 

```go
fr, err := slice.pixelData.Frames[0].GetEncapsulatedFrame()
fmt.Println(fr.Data)
f, _ := os.Create("test.jpg")
f.Write(fr.Data)
f.Close()
```
to get the underlying data, which appears to indeed be parsed into the construct. That could be a good place to start the debug--is the data encoded in an odd way, perhaps using some of the newer JPEG codecs that maybe aren't supported by the Go stdlib? 

At the very least, you should have access to the byte data to then try to render or process downstream. I think if this is an issue with the JPEG codecs, it might be good to pull in a third part library to help decode some of this jpeg data.

@suyashkumar You are correct. I'm able to get the byte data from the encapsulated frame using the code above. The issue is the JPEG encoding.

The encoding of the images is **JPEG Lossless:Non-hierarchical, 1stOrderPrediction** (1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70)

After looking into this a bit, there doesn't seem to be an easy way to parse these. Apparently, [very few image readers support this codec](https://stackoverflow.com/a/37399895/5781184), which coincidentally [you noted back in 2018](https://github.com/gradienthealth/dicom/issues/24#issuecomment-408145964) 😜 . The std lib `image/jpeg` still [does not support it](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/22535) either.

Have you come across any way to parse these since? I've read that `cgo` might be able to run a [C dicom library that can handle the codec](https://stackoverflow.com/a/38496553/5781184), but that's obviously not ideal.

Ah, I was wondering if that was it! Great find, btw--I do remember thinking a little about this in the [past as you found](https://github.com/gradienthealth/dicom/issues/24#issuecomment-408145964), but luckily never directly ran into this situation yet 😅 .

I haven't looked into how complicated the implementation of LosslessJEPG might be, but for what it's worth it might be a pretty decent contribution to the Go stdlib, but unclear how common it is in the wild (particularly outside of DICOM). I too haven't found a lot of support or implementations of it yet. 

A quick search found [this JS library](https://github.com/rii-mango/JPEGLosslessDecoderJS) that appears to implement lossless jpeg. Might be worth trying to port this over into Go.

In the short term to unblock your usecase, it may not be terrible to have a secondary stage of processing where you can run the JPEG-LS bytes through another parser (like this Javascript one, or a C++ one, even if it's not directly part of the same go program). If you're doing batch processing, you can probably spin up a docker container with a shell script that runs your go program (which can write the JEPG bytes to a file) and then invokes a JS or C++ program to decode the JPEG and save it out into some other lossless format for the rest of your pipeline.

Is it important that your code be encapsulated into a single go program, or are you working with a non-batch use case (e.g. a server)?

Hi @selimyoussry, thank you for the detailed context. I think this proposed change makes sense to me, please feel free to submit a pull request to this repo! Contributions are very welcome. 

As for guidelines, I don't have any special requirements--I guess the main thing to keep in mind is that submitting a PR to this repo means you are okay licensing your patch under this repository's license (the standard MIT license). This is generally true of all of GitHub.

I have done some quick investigation, and I think I see what the issue is. 

It looks like the PixelData tag `(7FE0,0010)` can appear multiple times in a Dataset, in particular when it is part of an Icon Image Sequence.

In this case, when we parse that native pixel data, we must make use of tags that have appeared earlier (like `Rows`, `BitsAllocated`, etc). However, if we encounter the PixelData tag within an Icon Image Sequence, we need to fetch these tags from within the current sequence instead of from the global dataset. If we fetch them from the global dataset, we end up grabbing the values for the actual PixelData and not the icon!

Will look into a mitigation for this shortly. Will also keep this in mind for the rewrite. This only seems to be an issue for the native pixel data, which AFAIK is the main thing that requires looking back at the dataset to parse (encapsulated pixel data does not require "looking back").

You can see the WIP draft PR #79 that should quick fix this, and appears to work for the provided DICOMs (thanks again for those). There is one odd thing that I'd like to check out before merging, and maybe refactor to avoid some temporary copies either now or in a follow up PR.
Thanks for the upcoming contribution! Agreed, if there are other errors in NewParserFromFile, the file should be closed before returning
@IChocked For the fix, if we don't use `.file` variable anymore, feel free to remove it from the Parser structure.

Commented on the PR #76, I think we should be careful about trying to read the file all at once, and instead should continue to use the efficient buffered `io.Reader` API (for example, consider reading large files from a network filesystem). Since we support parsing data as it arrives (and emitting frames as they are parsed, even if we haven't read the whole dicom into memory) it would be good to preserve that behavior.

I think we should certainly close the file if NewParserFromFile returned with an error though! 

Also, perhaps it's worth not adding this in the 1.0 API, and simply leaving the [io.Reader interface](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/blob/s/1.0-rewrite/parse.go), forcing the caller to manage the source of the data (files, closing them, etc).

Though it's not the worst for the caller to do something like:
```go
p, err := dicom.NewParserFromFile(...)
if err != nil {
  // handle
}
defer p.Finish()  // caller may want to handle this error as well
```

The main reason this is in there is to support the ParseNext API, but I agree it's a little clunky to be managing the file on our end.

Since Parse already calls p.Finish, to adhere cleanly to the pattern above we may need to put some guards in place in case p.Finish is called multiple times (haven't looked too closely at this).
@suyashkumar I'm ok with @IChocked simple change (closing file). I like the idea of passing the reader interface for v1.0

Sounds good! Note that the [existing API](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/blob/8abd37b0527758076982254a1862c972aeb6e1c8/parse.go#L43) also does allow a user to call `NewParser` and supply an io.Reader, but the `NewParserFromFile` was added as a convenience method, which perhaps we'll consider leaving out in the 1.0 API.

Interesting--this error originates from [FindByTag](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/blob/661f45d57717eaa29aa9775796a4fea18fb0943a/element/element.go#L338) and essentially indicates that the Rows element `(0028,0010)` doesn't exist in this DICOM, and some caller is asking for it. 

Are you getting this when running `dicomutil` CLI to get the native or encapsulated image? The Rows tag is important for [parsing native pixel data](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/blob/661f45d57717eaa29aa9775796a4fea18fb0943a/parse.go#L517)--without it, the pixeldata cannot be read properly. 

It might be interesting to see what kind of modality this dicom is, or if these collections of dicoms missing this tag come from some specific manufacturer?

@jacobalberty thank you for the information, it's definitely useful to know that when writing the tags they should be in order! It may be useful to still represent the DataSet as a map of tag -> element (or pointer to element) so that it's easy to fetch elements by tag in large DataSets, without too much memory overhead. Thoughts?

Migrating DataSet to use map also will make it easier to convert a DataSet to DICOM JSON model and the tag key will be sorted.

[https://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/]() 
`Map values encode as JSON objects. The map's key type must either be a string, an integer type, or implement encoding.TextMarshaler. The map keys are sorted and used as JSON object keys by applying the following rules, subject to the UTF-8 coercion described for string values above:

- keys of any string type are used directly
- encoding.TextMarshalers are marshaled
- integer keys are converted to strings`

When writing the Dataset to a DCM file, sort the keys first, and range map through the ordered keys, then write each element to the file.
Something like this was done in #97.

Should be closed as we migrated away from dep (#45).

The key here is should the PixelData `Element`'s value be a raw-ish representation of a Frame or an interface that lets the caller retrieve a processed version of that Frame as an `image.Image` (and in doing so, the caller is invoking some unseen magic to make that happen). 

Seeing as the interface will still allow the user to get the appropriate underlying `NativeFrame` or `EncapsulatedFrame` similar to the current `Frame` struct, I'm leaning towards this interface.
Also, I do not really like `element.DataSet` ... perhaps `DataSet` should get its own package at some point, or the `element` package should get a different name.
we should consider putting many of these packages into `pkg/`. However I do like having the main API exposed at the top level (can just import and use `github.com/suyashkumar/dicom`)...
Should be closed by #45.

Awesome! 

Yep, so in dicom there are two broad types of image data: Encapsulated images (compressed in some way) and Native images (which are usually stored in the dicom as 16 bit ints). You can see how native pixel data is turned into a jpg [here](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/blob/master/dicomutil/dicomutil.go#L137) (autoscaling will need to be implemented at some point) and you can see how it's parsed out of the dicom [here](https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/blob/master/parse.go#L521). 

Thing with encapsulated data is that it can be encoded using one of many formats (JPEG-2000, JPEG-LS, MPEG, etc), though usually it's some type of JPG. Check out more here: http://dicom.nema.org/dicom/2013/output/chtml/part05/sect_8.2.html 

Right now the `dicomutil` assumes the data is some sort of jpeg and writes the binary image data out to disk with a `.jpg` file name as you see here: https://github.com/suyashkumar/dicom/blob/master/dicomutil/dicomutil.go#L132 .

That endpoint is no longer supported by Riot since #getMatchListByAccountId() can yield exactly the same result now. Instead they suggest using #getMatchListByAccountId(). It is not marked as deprecated in the official Api documentation yet, but since Riot explicitly recommends to not use it anymore, we decided to deprecate this method.

If you need exactly the behavior of that method, the following call should return the same result:

> getMatchListByAccountId(platform, accountId, null, null, null, -1, -1, -1, 20)


See: https://discussion.developer.riotgames.com/articles/3241/update-on-matchlist-and-recent-endpoints.html

The DefaultRateLimitHandler of this library only handles rate limits after it is too late. So basically if you already got a 429 response from the Riot Api, it will try to respect the Retry-After header for the given service, method or app.

There is also a BufferedRateLimitHandler in the current version of this library that, when configured properly, will try to prevent 429 responses by stopping to fire new requests early. Basically what it does is after a request it reads the rate limit headers from the Riot Api's response, and if the current usage is above X%, it will issue a manual X second cooldown on making requests to the given endpoint(s).

In a later version we also want to provide an AtomicRateLimitHandler (currently WIP) that tries to properly keep track of your rate limits by counting the requests you make and stopping a request when it would exceed the rate limit.

You can also write your own rate limiting logic by implementing the RateLimitHandler interface or extending the DefaultRateLimitHandler class. To use a non-default RateLimitHandler, use the #setRateLimitHandler() method of your ApiConfig.

For my personal use I created a custom RedisRateLimitHandler that basically uses a dedicated redis server to atomically manage rate limits for multiple dedicated servers using the same api key. This library is designed to give you a lot of freedom to create a RateLimitHandler that suits your specific use case best.


In any case, regardless of if the Riot Api throws a 'real' RateLimitException or if the RateLimitHandler of your choice prevents making a call (in which case it will throw a RespectedRateLimitException, which inherits RateLimitException), your request will fail and you will not get a response from it. What you can do is catch RateLimitException when you do a request. On that RateLimitException object you can call #getRetryAfter() which will give you an integer that is the amount of seconds you need to wait before you can fire the request again.
It depends on the specific application if your best choice would be to sleep and retry the request, or drop it entirely.

I currently can't remember exactly what, but I ran into some major issues with regex validated summoner names, that's why I left it out.

I believe some regions (like Turkey) have allowed characters outside the regex given by Riot. Also given the fact that the set of allowed characters for each region (or even new regions in future) could change without notice, this is a pretty unmaintainable solution.

I think the discussion I had about it in discord ended up suggesting to only check if all characters are valid UTF-8 characters, since everything else is pretty unnecessary and unmaintainable, or simply only filter out empty strings.

That being said, even with the current implementation of only checking for empty strings, and allowing user input for summoner names, I don't hit any 400 responses anymore and only a very tiny amount of 404 responses (which ultimately are caused by searching non-existing summoners with legit characters).

So like I said, I'm highly uncomfortable with checking summoner names using regex because sooner or later this would cause unnecessary trouble.


Just for the sake of completeness, these are the *currently* allowed characters for each region: https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752814-Summoner-Name-FAQ#h1q5 -- So if you were to really tryhard, you would even have to specify this validation function *per platform*, and limit it to those characters only. At this point you should probably see how stupid and unmaintainable things would get. Also there is no guarantee that this article will always be up-to-date (or even is up-to-date right now).

One more addendum: Just to show an example on how quick these character sets could change, a few months ago the German language (within the EUW region) recently officially created a capitalized version of the letter ß (ẞ). Prior to that there only was the uncapitalized version. (Basically this is because words never start with ß, so there was no need for a capitalized version of that letter. But there came up some trouble in the age of technology when people with a "ß" in their name got their name capitalized in some documents, which, as per grammar rules, would turn "ß" into "SS" and therefor technically putting a wrong name in their documents. If you care about this little off-topic story, you could continue reading here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capital_%E1%BA%9E) So, while ẞ is not listed as legit character for EUW, it might soon become one.

IMO, for most use cases, match data should be persisted long term as well, as the only thing that changes is new games since the last query. If you need to hit the endpoint often and find yourself reaching your rate limit, you may need to get creative and design your app in a way that doesn't require you to hit your limit as often. A good example of apps that do this is OP.gg's 'Update' button for summoner profiles. Only data users truly care about is requested and it is cached for later use.

If you can't get the data you need for your current project with your current limit, that is a discussion you will need to have with Riot, as we cannot do anything about that.

The documentation you are referring to was outdated.

The documentation has been updated to reflect the latest Riot Games API v3 changes.

If the Riot API returns `NULL` (or no value) for "image", then you can't access its subvalues (like "full"). Make sure to check `item.getImage()` for `NULL` before calling `item.getImage().getFull()`.

Is there a specific item that causes this issue? It's probably worth checking out the raw API response for that item.

Not all data is returned by the static data endpoints by default intentionally to reduce payload size.

Taken from the implementation notes of the endpoint from the official documentation of the Riot Games API:

> Not all data specified below is returned by default. See the tags parameter for more information.

If you want more data than is provided by default you will need to provide a tag using the overloaded method:

`getDataItemList(Platform platform, Locale locale, String version, ItemListTags... tags)`

In your case you will want to provide ItemListTags.GOLD and ItemListTags.IMAGE or simply ItemListTags.ALL.

Otherwise, all the data that isn't included will be null/false/0 (depending on the data type of the field.)

We can probably document this better, or at least include equivalent documentation to what is provided in the Riot Games API documentation, as I see this question a lot and it is pretty confusing that the method without the optional parameters doesn't return all data by default.
Thank you very much!

We had the topic of caching come up a few times already, but maybe you can add something new to the discussion.

If we wanted to cache API calls, there are alot of open questions. Probably the biggest of all would be:

**Where to cache data?**
You could cache data in memory, but that would quickly become an enormous memory eater. Just take the matches endpoint for example, I just picked a random match from the Api and get a result that is 32261 characters in size, which approximately equals ~32 KB, assuming you cache the json String. If you were to cache the actual DTOs, it would probably be much bigger. It's not unusual that projects request hundreds of thousands or even millions of matches to calculate averages for certain things -- that would quickly sum up many GB of cache and end up in a java.lang.OutOfMemoryError and crash the application on many low-tier servers. Of course you could provide options to limit the cache size or allow uncached calls to go around this.
Alternatively you could store the cache on disk, maybe create a "cache" folder and store files there for each cached call. The big advantage is that your memory keeps clean and your cache survives a restart of the application. The downsides are that this would slow down the server, if it has to open and close files constantly. Also depending on your system, you might eventually run into "Too many open files" errors.
You could also cache your calls in third party databases or third party caching tools like memcached -- and if your project gets too big to run on a single dedicated server you eventually have to use a dedicated caching option, since local caching kinda gets pointless when running multiple instances. Each option has their advantages and disadvantages -- so what would we choose to provide with this api wrapper? Basically there is no general right or wrong, it simply depends on the specific use case of the developers using this api wrapper.


I personally belong to the latter category -- I have projects too big to be run on a single dedicated server, so a local cache is not really going to help my use case. Instead I use a memcached server for short-term caching and a few mariadb database servers for long-term caching.

There are many projects dedicated to caching data for tons of different use cases. I think every developer should decide on their own what caching method suits their needs. I personally don't believe there is *the one* caching method that's right for everyone, so I think it would be wrong to force one caching method upon everyone using this api wrapper. Also with the many caching options already being offered by other dedicated projects, it would kinda be like reinventing the wheel.


What are your thoughts on this?

Well at first this is just a simple caching method for those small users who frequently access the same data, and it makes the code much cleaner. Instead of storing all the objects you need after calling once the Riot API, you just repeatedly call getSummonerByName for example. Then in your code there would be much less variables. Also, since my project is currently just a naive way to cache data, I can't really talk about memory efficiency. I could easily add in a cache size limit, since we know the average size of all the DTOs, and I just have to limit the map sizes for each DTO type.

I'm more for offering easier options for developers than forcing them to use something. People can use both cached and uncached methods.

Caching on disk would be a bit overkill in my opinion, as the rate limit imposed by Riot are not that limiting, especially for the application APIs. Maybe it would be somewhat useful for the developer API limit, but I still don't really see a use for it, a limited memory cache would be the best way to go in my opinion, as those who request millions of matches can figure a way to cache their own information (eg. cache the win ratio and use it to recalculate using only new matches instead of going through the list again).

Also, do you have some average usage/memory figures for common applications? Then we can figure out a way to deal with the extreme use case scenarios.

After considering extreme use scenarios, I think a hybrid method would be best (storing common data in memory and all the rest on disk), but then, as you stated, there are Database libraries that already do this. 
I don't think there is a need to overcomplicate things. Most people just need a simple API, that does things in a simple way (so it doesn't always break), just like what this api provides. riot-api-java is a very lightweight wrapper, and that is what I want to respect too with riot-api-java-cached. Keeping things simple is usually the best way to go.

For now, I will add a "purge" method in my API, so people can use a timer or purge the cache by themselves, then I will figure out an automatic way of clearing the cache or keeping the cache small.

Thanks for reminding me of those extreme use scenarios, I always seem to forget them...

I would suggest the library define an interface for caching and with one
(or maybe a couple) implementations, and then let others come up with other
implementations.  Memory, disk, memcache, redis, JDBC, so many ways people
might want to store and expire the content.

It is generally advised that you do **not** use the QueueType enum to check against a league's queueType. The reason is that leagues are not mapped to Queues 1:1. There might be multiple queues that count towards the same league. For example the queues RANKED_SOLO_5x5 and TEAM_BUILDER_RANKED_SOLO both had their games count towards the RANKED_SOLO_5x5 league. Also the name of a league does not have to match the name of any queue at all -- note that *theoretically* Riot could change this in future on short notice.

That being said, you should **always** check the result from an api call for `null`, at least when getting a non-Collection. For Collections, it is admittingly bad practice to have them return as `null` -- they should return empty Collcetions instead. That is something I will look into for the upcoming version 4.0.0 of this api wrapper.

As for your code, other than missing the `null` check it looks fine. My guess would be that the summoner you are looking up is not ranked in any league of the queueType RANKED_SOLO_5x5.

However, I do think having a utility method to easily grab participants by their ID is a good suggestion and a more correct way of retrieving the participant data, as there's nothing guaranteeing that the indices of the participants will always be equal to `particpantID-1`. `1` in this case just seems like some magic number bullshit that could change tomorrow if Riot updates participant IDs to be something other than `1-10`.

To get item, champion, or spell data by their IDs, you need to use the static data endpoints.

The methods for these endpoints start with getData...

For example, you can get data for a champion (including their name) by calling the method getDataChampion(), and passing in the champion ID as a parameter.

If you don't want to make calls for each individual champion, you can use the List variant of the method (getDataChampionList) to get data for all champions, and cache it for later use.

queue types, game modes, and maps however are all game constants, and can be accessed using an enum.

You can find those [here.](https://github.com/taycaldwell/riot-api-java/tree/master/src/main/java/net/rithms/riot/constant)

You can be banned if you exceed your rate limits constantly, but if you back off for the amount of time specified in the retry after header. You could go fancier using the Rate Limit Count Header too, but unless you're running something intense that requires the utmost optimization on your end, it is very likely overkill.

Outside of exposing the `X-Rate-Limit-Count` header included in the API response, I have no intention to implement metrics of API usage in the library.

The goal of `riot-api-java` is to simply serve as a wrapper around the Riot Games API.

If you would like to continue discussion on how we could implement features to better improve rate-limit handling and throttling, please reference the currently open issue: https://github.com/taycaldwell/riot-api-java/issues/77

I have removed all of the unconventional field names in DTOs brought on from the inconsistencies found across endpoints in the Riot Games API. GSON will now map certain field names returned from the API to member variable names that follow the Java convention.

This means you should no longer have any issues using libraries like Jackson which assume a specific POJO convention.
