Sure, but for consistency sake we would have to add this for all the data objects. This leaves open the following questions:

1.) Which fields should be included/excluded for each DTO? Will all fields be included, or just fields deemed "important".
2.) What format should the information be printed in? (a list of values with no context, JSON, a line by line list of the field names and their values, etc.)

IMO a toString method should be a String representation of the object, but you mention using it to display only key information.

For example, when it comes to a toString() method for a League entry of a summoner, what is the expected output? Some may expect the output to be the JSON returned from the API, some may expect just the Tier of the summoner, some may expect Tier and Division, some may expect Tier, Division, League name, LP, etc.

If the method output doesn't match majority of developer expectations, they will just end up using the individual accessors for key information anyways, making the toString method useless.

I received an email a while ago from someone asking how to get the name of a summoner because the toString() method wasn't working. I had to advise him to use the getName() method instead. This is an example of someone who would have different expectations than me.

IMO, if I were using a toString() method on a data object from this library, I would expect a JSON String with all the data returned by the Riot API. I don't understand why I would ever use that, but having a toString() method for objects would make the library more complete.

TL;DR: I'm down with having toString() methods, I'm just interested in hearing your opinion (and anyone elses) to the questions listed above.

Here's my point of view:
1. Only important field should be included. It would be then a matter of perspective to decide what is "important". But I'd say that the `toString()` method can be useful when logging and debugging your applications. You simply want to log your object to have some trace of it, and instead of having a useless memory pointer, you'd have some information.
   The minimum "useful" information would be the technical id (of champion, league, etc.). Like I said, it's a matter of perspective and for a Summoner I'd put `(Id, Name)`.
2. No JSON format, as I think it's not the idea behind the Java toString() method. I like this notation : (val1; val2; val3), or (key1:val1; key2:val2; ...). JSON encoding should be delegate to transformation libraries that serializes DataObjects to JSON/XML formats.

If a developer want to access specific information, of course that he should use getters methods to retrieve it, and not toString(). It's just a matter of not being disappointed when you put your objects in some log and have nothing practical to use... ;)

In my opinion there are only two ways for deciding what goes into toString():
1. Either make it minimalistic and only use some sort of 'primary keys' (for summoners this would be ID and name, for matches this would be the matchID, etc.)
2. Or make it complete and plot all fields. In some other projects I have toString() methods on some objects that print out every single field, much like this:

```
UserObject {
    id: 1337
    name: asd
    level: 1
}
```

It's not exactly JSON, but very easy to read and get information from when you're debugging. I think I would prefer the second way for the following reason: You are only ever going to print a data object when you're debugging, and more information is always good when debugging.

Yeah, it doesn't have to be JSON. I was just using that as an example, since it has easy-to-read notation. Any format that uses key-value pairs should be fine. I like and prefer @Linnun's second example for the same reasons given, but I also think there might be a happy medium between the two that might be useful for data objects with tons of not-so-useful fields.

Would it be weird to have some kind of global 'verbose' flag which makes toString() methods output the complete data objects (all fields) while without that flag it would only return 'basics'?

I'm not entirely sure if this generally is a well-designed idea though. Also not entirely sure if ApiConfig is a proper place for this.

It would feel a bit weird to me to put it in ApiConfig. I like the idea of being able to switch the verbosity of the output though.

If we wanted to do something like that, I think the simplest way would be to implement an overloaded method such as toString(boolean verbose), rather than overriding the toString() method, and maybe have toString() default to the laconic output.

I started implementing such a functionality, but I stumbled upon difficulties with recursively printing a Dto and passing the verbosity flag on to childs when they are part of a list.

Example:

ChampionList contains a List<Champion>. Since List does not have a toString(boolean verbose) method, it will use the default toString() method of List, causing it to call the parameter-less toString() method of its items; so verbosity is not passed on to the Champion elements of the list.

While this is reasonably okay-ish for verbosity (you could say we don't want verbosity on each single list item), I also tried to pass on a `int depth` parameter, so that we would have some indentation to make it look pretty.

What you said makes sense to me regarding DTOs. If you are using the DTO directly, I can see how the lack of setters can make things difficult when implementing a DAO interface with update methods and stuff.

Outside of the issues you would run into with persistence and DAOs, there aren't too many reasons for these objects to have setter methods, which is why they don't have them now.

I totally understand your reasoning though, and am not against just generating setters for all of the DTOs, or at least the ones it makes most sense to do so.

It's been a while since I've given this library attention. Someone feel free to chime in if I'm missing something.

I haven't gotten too deep into the api just yet but at a glance it would be a lot more convenient than making wrappers for all of the DTO's that might want a DAO implementation or setters for some other reason.

When the Data you're handling is immutable, a Dto without setters makes a lot of sense. This doesn't mean you can't change the values, since you can always make a new instance with the changes you need. This does require more code to do small changes, but it also ensures that once you have a reference of an object it won't be tampered with. 

This is how Strings work in Java (with some help from the compiler to lower the boilerplate code), and it is also how many functional languages implement their collections.

Hi vBandiTv,

The Riot Games API has two different League endpoints.

One to get **the entire league of a summoner** (includes entries of the other 99 summoners in that same league): 

https://euw.api.pvp.net/api/lol/euw/v2.5/league/by-summoner/62128873,%2019881488?api_key=<API-KEY-GOES-HERE>

The library method that uses this endpoint is **getLeagueBySummoners()**.

and one just to get **the league entry of a summoner**, (only includes the summoners specified): 

https://euw.api.pvp.net/api/lol/euw/v2.5/league/by-summoner/62128873,%2019881488/entry?api_key=<API-KEY-GOES-HERE>

The library method that uses this endpoint is **getLeagueEntryBySummoners()**.

The reason you're getting the wrong division is you're using the method to get all the summoners in the same League as the summoners provided, and looking at the first entry of that list, which will likely be the data for a random summoner rather than the one you wanted.

**TLDR: Based on the URL given in your example, I believe you want to use the method getLeagueEntryBySummoners() rather than getLeagueBySummoners().**

Kind of confusing and easy to mix up. I'll think of a way to better clarify things like this for the future.

Hope this helps.

One more question (I dont want to create a new issue).

The method getTopChampionMasteries() have an enum PlatformId.
What is the difference between the Enum PlatformId and the Enum Region?

From what I understand, Riot's API is powered by a bunch of different underlying systems, owned by different teams. Because of this, there's a bit of inconsistency found between endpoints. Some endpoints expect a Region, some expect a PlatformID. 

From what I've heard, PlatformID and Region are different, because it is possible that a region can have multiple PlatformIDs. However, the current the relationship between region and platform ID is one-to-one, so there is essentially no difference between the two at this point in time.

As library designers, we _could_ have abstracted the concept of a PlatformID, and just used the Region enum for all methods, but we decided against this in case the one-to-one mapping between Region and PlatformID changes in the future.

**TLDR: They are basically the same thing with different names. Some methods expect a PlatformID, some methods expect a Region.**

Technically the current master branch should be complete and working, but we need to do more testing before we can release 4.0 of this wrapper. I'm personally already using the current master branch in a test environment for my production applications, and so far it seems to be stable and working correctly for the methods that I'm actively using.

A lot has changed since the last release. This has various reasons, most significantly the conversion to Riot Api v3.

When converting from v3.8 or v3.9 to v4.0, all of the old method calls will need to be adjusted because methods no longer use a `Region` but a `Platform` parameter now due to the Riot Api v3 drifting away from regions and going towards platforms exclusively. Other than that, batch calls are no longer supported by Riot Api v3, and thus have been removed from this wrapper aswell. Methods might also have their parameters or return DTOs adjusted to reflect other changes to the Riot Api endpoints.


Since old Riot Api methods are deprecated and you will need to do the switch soon either way, I would recommend that you use the latest master branch to create your code and switch to the full release of v4.0.0 later. Please let us know if you happen to find any issues.

The String is the callback URL in which the League of Legends servers will send data after a tournament game is completed.

This lets you receive game data (such as which team won/lost) after each tournament game finishes.

You should set up some URL that the League of Legends servers can make a callback to via HTTP POST.

For testing purposes, if you are just interested in generating tournament codes, and don't care for receiving data from the League of Legends servers after each game, you can just provide a dummy URL like "http://test.com".

If you are interested in this data, you will need to setup your server with a callback URL for the League of Legends servers to callback. It can be anything really... like "http://mysupercoolwebsite.com/api/awesomeCallbackURL". As long as it sends back a 200 response upon success, and is on port 80, you're golden.

More detailed information and examples can be found under the **Server Callback** section of the official [Tournaments API Documentation](https://developer.riotgames.com/docs/tournaments-api).

I'm unsure what you mean, but -

As Linnun said, if you want to get the name of the image for a spell, you can use the ID along with the method **to get a specific spell**:

``` java
api.getDataSummonerSpell(id, null, null, SpellData.IMAGE);
```

If you just want to make a single call **to get all spells**, you can use the method :

``` java
api.getDataSummonerSpellList(null, null, false, SpellData.IMAGE);
```

This method is useful when you want to just make one call to the API and cache the data, rather than making a call for each individual spell you need.

[SummonerSpellList](https://github.com/rithms/riot-api-java/blob/887c7896e9813a4970c90c139b5e35903d6b7683/src/main/java/net/rithms/riot/api/endpoints/static_data/dto/SummonerSpellList.java) doesn't have anything to do with buffering repeated calls. It's just a list of ALL spells returned from the second method above, rather than just one specific spell returned from the first method above.

This is the method head for `getDataSummonerSpellList`:

`public SummonerSpellList getDataSummonerSpellList(String locale, String version, boolean dataById, SpellData... spellData) throws RiotApiException`

Use `true` as value for `dataById` to receive summoner spells by id.

In your case you may want to call:

`api.getDataSummonerSpellList(null, null, true, SpellData.IMAGE)`

Note that the keys will still be strings, but the strings will be Spell IDs instead of Spell names.

Image data shouldn't be returning null if you specified that you want Image data to be included using ChampData parameters.
I think I answered your question on how include image data in this issue - https://github.com/rithms/riot-api-java/issues/51#issuecomment-186664993

If you are using **getDataChampionList(Region region, String locale, String version, boolean dataById, ChampData... champData)** and specifying that you want image data included,

For example - 

``` java
ChampionList championList = api.getDataChampionList(Region.NA, null, null, false, ChampData.IMAGE);
```

and you are still receiving null values, something is wrong and I would ask you to provide a code example so we can look into it.

With that said, Ddragon doesn't name image files after the champion's **name**, it is named after champion **keys**. For many champions, name and key are the same, but for others this is not the case (i.e. The champion key for Wukong is MonkeyKing, and the name of his image file on ddragon is MonkeyKing.png).

Thus, using the value returned from **getKey()** rather than **getName()** should solve your issue.

You're talking about the getRecentGames() method.
This method uses the game-v1.3 endpoint of the Riot Games API.
The documentation for the endpoint specifies that the data type used for the games is a Set<Game>.
When I first created the library I stuck strictly to this documentation to make it as consistent as possible.

As time went on, we have improved the library and deviated from the documentation if it makes more sense and provides convenience for developers.

Regardless of the documentation, the endpoint returns the games in a JSON array, and it looks like it is ordered. I see no reason why we cannot update the library to return a List instead. With that said, we are currently working on version 4 of the library which includes some pretty major changes.
So you won't see any updates like this till version 4 is released.

@rithms That is nice, however, I am getting a null object from that function. Is that intended ?

By default the static data champion API only returns information like champion ID, name, and key. 
Which is pretty smart on Riot's part. Why give you data you don't want? It's a waste.
To get more data, you must specifically request it using the available query parameters.

You are probably using the method that specifies no query parameters:
**getDataChampionList(Region region)**
So you are only getting back a Champion object with an ID, name, and key. Everything else you didn't specify is null.

You can use the overloaded method:
**api.getDataChampionList(Region region, String locale, String version, boolean dataById, ChampData... champData)**

to ask for more information:

For example, to get champion image data:

``` java
ChampionList championList = api.getDataChampionList(Region.NA, null, null, false, ChampData.IMAGE);
```

or, to get champion image data, and information about champion skins:

``` java
ChampionList championList = api.getDataChampionList(Region.NA, null, null, false, ChampData.IMAGE, ChampData.SKINS);
```

or to get ALL champion data, without having to specify each individual parameter:

``` java
ChampionList championList = api.getDataChampionList(Region.NA, null, null, false, ChampData.ALL);
```

Hey,

I prefer people to open issues rather than contact me on Twitter. It's sometimes hard to fit everything in 140 characters.

I'm down to add or merge stuff from your existing codebase, but it would have to take into consideration whats already in place, and likely be modified to fit. We don't want existing code breaking, or require people to completely rewrite their existing apps if they want to use the latest changes and features. 

I don't feel like this should be a big issue with adding features like persistence and rate limit throttling, but when you talk about re-structuring things, we have to be careful about that.

We have a lot of contributors already, so I have no problem with you opening pull requests to contribute. I'm always happy to add more people as collaborators, but I want to make sure whoever I add as a collaborator understands the codebase enough to make quality contributions. 

For example, I recently added Linnun the CEO of lolskill.net as a collaborator, because he has been a long time contributor, has numerous quality pull requests, has a large codebase using the library, and probably knows more about it than me at this point. :)
Roughly how many projects are using your source? I'm working on uploading all the stuff I have done right to my own github.

I'm personally a big fan of using design patterns, so I especially like your idea of making this library a factory. While this might have some advantages for the future, we obviously would break every single project using this code. It's hard to estimate how many projects are currently using this API and would be affected by this change, but with a proper note in the release notes I don't see much of a problem there.

Throttling and caching might be useful for some small project, but must definitely be optional features, since they won't work for big-scaling projects.
For example, I'm using one API code for a project that has multiple different applications, so I can't simply enter my rates into a single app. Also I run multiple instances of each app on different servers (for load balancing etc.) - making it even harder to properly throttle the rates.
Caching is a troubly topic for the same reasons - having multiple instances of an app across multiple servers makes it hard to cache data. You could be lucky to have the same request on the same server twice within the caching time, but in practice the second request is more likely to land on a different server - ultimatively you'll end up caching every request but will hardly ever make use of the cached data.
Also you may not want to cache every kind of method call. Let's say a user wants to look up his game, but he hits the button too early and gets a "not ingame" message. If he hits the button again 5 seconds later, the cache might keep telling him that he is not ingame, even though he actually is. Same issue the other way around: The game ended and the user started a new game, but the cache will still show his old game. These are just some of the issues I already had to deal with when building my custom caching methods - there is definitely alot to keep in mind.

While I don't mind having some basic caching or throttling methods, this definitely is not a high priority in my eyes.

Yeah, it's really hard to tell how many projects are using this library, as I'm only aware of the people that tell me and can estimate based off the amount of questions and emails I get.

> We don't want existing code breaking, or require people to completely rewrite their existing apps if they want to use the latest changes and features.

I noticed this quote by me might be misleading. It is _preferred_ we don't break people's code, but we have done so in the past to up the quality of the library. When we do, we just mention it in the release notes (Like we did in [the latest release](https://github.com/rithms/riot-api-java/releases/tag/v3.7.0)). I didn't mean for it to sound like we can't improve the structure and quality of the existing code at all.

Thanks for providing your source. I should have time this weekend, so I'll look over it too.

>  I'm very unhappy with how you hard-fix the rates in the code like this:

Yeah, me too.

I would actually like to solve the general problem of: given _N_ time windows of _M_ requests each design a class that maximizes number of requests from _X_ clients without any client ever receiving a 429 response. The current `RiotApiThrottle` does maximize number of requests without getting a single 429, however _X_ is bound to 1 (that is only a single client can be in use at once, Linnun raised this point earlier when he mentioned load balancing) and the time windows are hardcoded. There is a technology called [HornetQ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HornetQ) that can help make it possible for distributed computing nodes (like load balanced servers) to synchronize critical components like rate throttles. Setting up HornetQ can be nasty, nor do I know how invasive it would be to make existing code compatible.

Additionally, a single `Thread` object pulls tasks from a queue. In a real high-speed environment this queue would become prohibitively large and, because it's managing an `ArrayBlockingQueue`, will actually cause the thread posting tasks (see `throttle.post(..)`) to block. In a real world application this would cause your UI thread or request processing thread to hang, not good.

Finally, it should be using a `ThreadPool` not a single thread. I did try using a thread pool originally, but I ran into some bugs on Riot's side. The best thing the current throttle did for me was show me the non-obvious issue that you have to time requests from the time you receive the response, not the time you send the response. It seems that Riot sets times on when the request completes. They also seem to like a 1.5 second buffer. So the throttling service is certainly a work in progress.

What about using [guava - RateLimiter](http://docs.guava-libraries.googlecode.com/git/javadoc/com/google/common/util/concurrent/RateLimiter.html)  for Rate Limiting?
Add the rate limits to e.g. riot-api.properties. When nothing is defined, ignore the rate limiting, else use those from the file.

The token bucket approach is really close to what I want. I still get a few 429's when I run it, but it's pretty elegant. Thanks for turning me on to that library. I'm currently working this issue with a thread pool and I'm really close to having a solid, truly asynchronous, blazing fast, memory efficient method of rate controlling. I am also working on leaving hooks in place to integrate load balancing and the likes.

But I really like this simplicity of this approach. 10 / 10.

What do you think? It has no multi-node support, but I assume this would be very hard to implement without a db. The consuming of the tokens is syncronised, but the connections are multithreaded.

So the main difference with our stuff is that the solution that I came up with is more of a scheduler than a throttler. That is, when a request comes in the scheduler looks into the future and determines when a request can execute. It does not delay until a time has passed then allows a request to execute. This allows for some slick usage of Java's scheduling thread pool. My repo is https://github.com/dancarpenter21/lol-api-java and if you want to check stuff out look at the class org.dc.riotapi.service.scheduler.RiotApiScheduler.java. It's a pretty complex class but the gist is that the `schedule` method adds a callback to a ThreadPool for execution. The service then analyzes network rates and conditions to approach an ideal speed based on rate rules and outside factors. The issue that's going to arise now is all these asynchronous calls are resulting in callback hell when I want to do anything real. Since every request that I want to be throttled has to be passed in as a `Runnable` essentially there's a lot of inner class nesting going on. I also need to add a nice way to handle 429 codes but I do have a strategy in mind. I might be able to add that tonight. In all I think my approach will perform well, but might be too unwieldy to be useful. I definitely feel that a Reactive approach is the way to go here.

I know about the RiotApiException, but sometimes there are some other issues with the connection, for example:

java.net.ConnectException: Connection timed out
or
javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Remote host closed connection during handshake
or
java.io.EOFException: SSL peer shut down incorrectly

I get tons of exceptions every day, and it's hard to say which exact exception leads to which exact behavior, especially since I have a pretty big backend application using this API, running billions of requests every month.

Also, it's really hard to debug connection exceptions, like those mentioned above, since we can't manually test those cases. Also I'm still not sure when and why these occur.

(edit to clarify: only a few out of very many requests are affected by connection exceptions, but still it happens a few times everyday. I'm trying to find/fix/workaround those cases since a long time, but it's not easy at all)

This is something I would eventually like to add. In the mean time, check out another Riot Games API library, [Orianna](https://github.com/robrua/Orianna). 

It provides the following features you might be interested in -
- Caches static data and summoner information to accelerate access and reduce API load 
- Available automatic databasing using Hibernate.

To me this seems more of a design issue rather than a technical issue. Adding caches is a piece of cake with Guava, but making an intuitive cache configuration isn't as simple.

From what I remember, you can let Guava expire your cache by time or by amount of items in cache.  You could set a single value for each used by every API and just optionally pass it to the constructor. I don't think this is an optimal solution since you might want to cache things differently. For example, summoner data you might want to expire by time, match data you might want to expire based on how many so your RAM doesn't fill up excessively and static data you might not want to ever expire at all.

If we can reach a consensus for a good design that covers most people's use cases, then getting the actual code in should be simple enough.
Ok, there's already a PlatformId class. I'll use it instead

Yeah, it already exists. I kinda like the idea of adding PlatformIds to Regions though. 

IIRC, the current-game endpoint is the only endpoint of the Riot Games API that makes use of PlatformId as a parameter.

Adding PlatformIds to Regions in the code allows us to abstract away the idea of PlatformIds from developers using the library, because we could make it so the current-game method converts from Region -> PlatformId.

In the end, we would have:
getCurrentGameInfo(Region region, long summonerId)

rather than:
getCurrentGameInfo(PlatformId platformId, long summonerId)

which matches all the other methods in the library that use Region parameters.
It would make using the library easier and more straight forward for developers, because they won't have to ask themselves what a 'platform id' is.

As a parameter; but I actually wanted to add PlatformID to the Region enum because of the new Match List method where the returned MatchReference includes matches' PlatformID and not the Region. This is a bit confusing, because I store matches per Region. I've ended up using "Region.getName().equals(PlatformId.getName() )" to check if the match retrieved is from the desired Region (because Match List may retrieve matches from ANY region if the summoner has transferred its account).

Anyway, are we sure that Region <-> PlatformId is, and will be, a 1-to-1 relationship?

Unfortunately the responses here are correct. You will need to create a proxy server to act as an intermediary. 

It isn't too hard to set up.

This will make it so instead of having your application contain the key and make requests such as:
https://na.api.pvp.net/api/lol/na/v1.2/champion?api_key=<API-KEY>

You can do:
https://myproxyserver.net/api/lol/na/v1.2/champion

and not have your key in your application.

The library can be used at the proxy server level or the application level, but if you use it at the application level, you will need to replace the request URL with your proxy server domain, and recompile the library.

I might make a tutorial on how to create a proxy server to use for a distributed application, and add a feature to the library so you can do something along the lines of:

RiotApi api = new RiotApi("proxyserver.net");

which replaces the https://na.api.pvp.net/ with your proxy. This would assume the proxy is set up route and handle query parameters properly though.

I would encourage doing all the processing at the server level however, and feed only what is needed to your app.

I understand what is said here, either decompiling the app or even ssl-mitm-ing would reveal the key for sure. However it is a shame having to maintain a server for a small app that you don't even know if it would have some users or not yet. 
On the other hand, having a proxy server will bring more troubles, like you'd need to authenticate somehow the client  with it so that no one can use that server apart from your app, not doing so would be the same situation as giving your rior api key away.

Thanks for your answers.

I was going to submit a pull request to do the opposite... remove all static cases.  It's not very manageable to me if I can't instantiate an application cleanly and need to hack a static field at the right sequence.
Can you give an example of what you mean?

I would also advise against having more static methods.

The RiotApi is not completely stateless as it relies on (Key, Region, Season) to shorten queries.

For some programs querying multiple regions, having those properties static would need we either have to
- Set them before each call
- Use the long version of the queries with the region as parameter

wich is more overhead than creating an object with the key as parameter.

Furthermore, this would make multi-threaded use of the library more difficult as you can not rely on 

``` java
RiotApi.setRegion(EU)
RiotApi.getFoo()
```

to return values from EU, has it might have been changed in another thread in between.

An object with state and static methods is more or less a Singleton, and I don't think the current design is well suited for this.

A way I could see this work is if you'd remove all state with chained methods, holding only the Key as a state (wich could also be problematic if you want to use 2 test keys if your application is not validated yet), and chain calls like
RiotApi.getRegion("EU").getChampions(foo...)

If the problem you want to eliminate is the constant use of the key, you could create a getApi() factory method that would create the RiotApi object based on a java .properties file holding the key.
I agree with fKunstner on this, but for the sake of discussion what do you think one would gain from making those methods static?

I see what you mean fKunstner, I didn't take those things into consideration.

@laazer I was making the assumption most applications only use one RiotApi object.

initialize a servlet, it needs a database connection, whatever else, it needs to load some static champions data.  How do I know it's safe to call for the static data because the API key is set?

That's just a trivial example.  Any app with more than a few dependencies becomes unmanageable to control the dependencies when code uses static.  You just end up having to create your own non-static objects that call the static behind the scenes.

parameters.

 **getDataItem** methods can now take multiple ItemData constant parameters.

 **getDataItemList** methods can now take multiple ItemListData constant
parameters.

 **getDataMastery** methods can now take multiple MasteryData constant
parameters.

 **getDataMasteryList** methods can now take multiple MasteryListData
constant parameters.

 **getDataRune** methods can now take multiple RuneData constant parameters.

 **getDataRuneList** methods can now take multiple RuneDataList constant
parameters.

 **getDataSummonerSpell** methods can now take multiple SpellData constant
parameters.

 **getDataSummonerSpellList** methods can now take multiple SpellData
constant parameters.

Can we get a comment from @rithms on why he didn't do it as the riot API where each rune has it's stat there without doing extra work to get it? Also any chance to update it and make this easier?

Thank you.

The reason you have to do the extra work is because getStats() returns a BasicDataStats object which has all possible stats as class variables. In Java, class variables (double) are initialized to 0. So when the translation from JSON String -> Java object happens, if a rune doesn't contain a value for that specific data, it will be left as 0.

I could of course, make an easier way, so you do not have to do all the extra work (brute forcing all the stats to check if they != 0, just to get the stats for one rune).

The question remains though, if I were to implement an easier way, what would be the best/most useful way to provide the data to you; how would you like the data to be stored? 

I am thinking of changing the getStats() method to return a Map<String, Double>? (ie. Key = FlatArmorMod, Value = 0.5471). Or maybe having a completely separate method, called getStatsMap() leaving the functionality of getStats() as is.

Let me know what you would think works best, and I can implement something to make it easier.

Or maybe just a getStat() method, that returns a the stat value, since runes really only ever have 1 stat.

The weird thing is, the official Riot Games API makes it seem as if it were possible for a rune to have more than one stat associated with it. So if there were ever updates to runes in the future, where runes could have multiple different stats, this would need to be addressed if changes were made to the library assuming otherwise.

Thank you for your reply.

The riot API returns one stat with the modifier and the value so i guess one stat would suffice...

I have updated to library to include a RuneStat class. The Rune class in the static data API contains a RuneStat instance variable called "stat".

A RuneStat object contains a type (String) and value (double) that can be accessed using getType() and getValue() respectively.

You can now do:

``` java
        RuneList static_runes = api.getDataRuneList(null, null, RuneListData.STATS);

        Map<String, Rune> runes_data = static_runes.getData();
        for (Entry<String, Rune> rune : runes_data.entrySet()){
            System.out.println(rune.getValue().getId());
            System.out.println(rune.getValue().getName());
            System.out.println(rune.getValue().getDescription());
            System.out.println(rune.getValue().getRune().getType());
            System.out.println(rune.getValue().getRune().getTier());
            System.out.println(rune.getValue().getStat().getType());
            System.out.println(rune.getValue().getStat().getValue());
            System.out.println("###########################");
        }
```

To easily get a respective runes stats.

You are right. Thanks for noticing, and fixing.

The problem comes from Android. You are not able to make internet connections in the main thread, that's what [AsyncTasks](http://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/AsyncTask.html) are for.

You'll encounter much more of these, check what LogCat is telling you and google the exception, there's always a stackoverflow Q&A about it.

fKunstner is correct. The API call is a network operation, therefore it must be performed off the main UI thread.

Fortunately, Android makes it easy for you through the use of AsyncTasks. 

You will need to create a new subclass that extends AsyncTask, and make the API call in the doInBackground method.

Also be sure to include the Internet permission to your app.

I can provide you with example code of what I am talking about when I get home.

Cheers, 
Rithms

because url is invalid
called URL is http://riot.~~~~~/by-name/??????api_key=kkkkkkkkhttp://riot.%7E%7E%7E%7E%7E/by-name/%EC%B9%B4%EC%8B%9C%EC%98%A4%EA%B0%80%ED%94%BC?api_key=kkkkkkkk.
riot server need /by-name/{{nickname}} and api_key={{kkkkkkk}}
but riot will parse /by-name/{{??????api_key=kkkkkkkk}} and api_key is null

so it need to adding urlencoding as "UTF-8"
ex:
api.getSummonersByName(URLEncoder.encode("?????", "UTF-8"));

but it not need to encoding when extracting ID

ex)

  name 'Boilr'

end

Follows the bash-compliant code i've added to my sources.

```
# Alias for 'boilr template use $1 .'
function boilr_use_shortcut() {
    ~/bin/boilr template use $1 . ${@:2}
}
# Alias for 'boilr template save . $1'
function boilr_save_shortcut() {
    ~/bin/boilr template save . $@
}

alias boilr='~/bin/boilr'
alias bs='boilr_save_shortcut'
alias bu='boilr_use_shortcut'
```

Usage:

```
bs python  # save project in working directory
bu python  # create project in working directory
```

The first thing I noticed when building the image was, that I need to mount two volumes from my host, since I think it makes no sense to create files with boilr just in the container.

How would you call boilr running with Docker?

An alternative could also be to use `docker-compose` for that, a `yml` file could look like:

```
version: '2'
services:
  boilr:
    image: schmunk42/boilr
    volumes:
      - ~/.config/boilr:/root/.config/boilr
      - ./:/project
```

I am using boilr since a while with this alias

    alias boilr="docker run -it --rm -v ${HOME}/.config/boilr:/root/.config/boilr -v ${PWD}:/project --workdir /project schmunk42/boilr"

Should be interchangeable with native usage.

If I understood your problem correctly, you are developing on `github.com/rawkode/boilr/...`,
but changes you've made are not used, since imports still use `github.com/tmrts/boilr/...`.

You can get around this by doing the following:

``` bash
go get github.com/tmrts/boilr OR git clone https://github.com/tmrts/boilr
cd $BOILR_REPO # Wherever
git remote add fork https://github.com/rawkode/boilr
```

And you can push your changes by using `git push fork <branch-id>`.

Let me know if it solves your problem

Chris thank you for trying out boilr.

What you need is already implemented and can be used as such:

``` json
{
    "ExpertMode": false,
}
```

Default value of ExpertMode will be false and the user will see a boolean prompt for true/false.

In template usage:

``` text
{{ If ExpertMode }}
....
{{ end }}
```

For more information please take a look at the [wiki pages](https://github.com/tmrts/boilr/). 
It explains the templating features of boilr.

For creating templates check [this page](https://github.com/tmrts/boilr/).

There is a little misunderstanding :wink:

I don't want to use `{{ If ExpertMode }}` in the templates. Its the initial questioning of the user that I'm interested in.

So if I define my condition stuff, the user gets asked about this question only if the condition is true.

`project.json`:

``` json
{
    "AppName": "Demo",
    "ExpertMode": false,
    "FolderName": {
        "value": "Demo",
        "condition": "ExpertMode"
    }
}
```

Example workflows:
1.)
- `boilr template use demo .`
- User gets asked: `Please choose a value for "AppName"`
- User gets asked: `Please choose a value for "ExpertMode"`
- User selects "false".
- Template engine does its magic.

2.)
- `boilr template use demo .`
- User gets asked: `Please choose a value for "AppName"`
- User gets asked: `Please choose a value for "ExpertMode"`
- User selects "true".
- User gets asked: `Please choose a value for "FolderName"`
- Template engine does its magic.

Cheers

Thank you for your detailed use case and feature request.

 We can assume that any successful template will have new features and bug fixes. But, I didn't consider updating used templates when the boilr templates are updated since the aim at the moment is to provide a starter boilerplate for users.

However, I can see the benefit of adding a mechanism as a plugin command (`boilr plugin X args`) with some modifications.

I think using `upgrade` might be confusing to people since templates are saved locally and they
might think it is for updating stored templates. Instead `migrate` might be a better name for this context.

In order to allow people to upgrade their used templates, the used template needs to be parsed but I'm not sure if that's the way to go. Instead, boilr can store the answers given to that particular template and then when asked `boilr plugin migrate <path>`, it can automatically use the same answers, but it might overwrite the changes so users **either**, need to be warned about this **or** as you suggested a read-only template mechanism can be implemented (e.g. `boilr use --read-only <template-name> <target-dir>`)

Cons of automatically using the answers:
- Needs execution records, if the template is used on machine A, can't be migrated on machine B

Cons of read-only templates:
- Introduces even more complexity from the users point of view since they need to know about doing read-only templates and then using the plugin. Instead a composed single command is better.

I like this idea: 

> boilr can store the answers given to that particular template and then when asked `boilr plugin migrate <path>`

Where they'd potentially be asked more questions if the newer version needed to. I'm totally ok with this feature starting out as a plugin. That's what we did with [helm](http://helm.sh/).

Personally, I think updating can be even simpler to begin with if a template could simply identify which files can be overwritten.

e.g. I create a project with boilr that creates a readme and a CI plan template. Then I add a bunch of code and update the readme. Then at some point the completely boilerplate CI template is updated. I should be able to run some sort of update that keeps all of my newly created files, does **not** overwrite the readme, but **does** overwrite the CI template.

@jdoklovic since we have started using git as the back-end, implementation of this feature is simplified considerably. 

What we want is basically a git-rebase:

1. User renders the template
2. User does some other modifications
3. Updated template is downloaded
4. A stash and rebase is performed on the previously executed & used template

There are some problems with this solution, such as rebase conflicts

That's expected. To convert the *"name of the links"* into a clickable hyperlink, you need another formula: `=HYPERLINK("https://"&$A$1&".wikipedia.org/wiki/"&B1)` (where `$A$1` is a reference to a cell with the language like `"en"`, and `B1` a reference to a cell with a *"name of the links"*).

Most probably you have exceeded your daily quota for URL Fetch calls that the plugin uses internally to communicate with the Wikipedia and Wikidata APIs. You can see the quota here: 
https://developers.google.com/apps-script/guides/services/quotas#current_quotas.

Thank you. For the time being, I will provide the documentation to review it later or to facilitate a Pull Request to others interested in the solution. 

**Wikipedia API limits to 500 pages**
 * View documentation for Category Members → https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/API:Categorymembers
 * If category contains more than 500 pages, the API call returns a new line <continue cmcontinue="page|514b4d392f392b292d4f314b011001dc0f|59817068" continue="-||"/>
 * E.g: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php?action=query&list=categorymembers&cmlimit=max&cmprop=title&cmtype=subcat%7Cpage&format=xml&cmnamespace=0&cmtitle=Category:Bacteria_genera
 * It is necessary to program n new calls by adding cmcontinue with the indicated value
 * E.g: https://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php?action=query&list=categorymembers&cmlimit=max&cmprop=title&cmtype=subcat%7Cpage&format=xml&cmnamespace=0&cmtitle=Category:Bacteria_genera&cmcontinue=page|2f3141314f4b392904098c2b292d4f314b3929098e011701dc16|56801168
Sure, [TRANSPOSE](https://support.google.com/docs/answer/3094262?hl=en).

The “first” corresponds to situations where there are more than one values for a property, for example president of France, the current value would be “Macron”, but other values would be “Hollande” or “Sarkozy”. When you select “first”, you would only get “Macron” (typically the value that most people would agree on right now). Hope this helps.
Ah, if you want to limit to just property P586, pass it as a string: `WIKIDATAFACTS(A2; "first"; "P586")`.

@susannaanas I have just released a new version of the addon that allows you to specify a Wikidata qid for `WIKIDATAFACTS` lookups like so: `WIKIDATAFACTS("Q42")`. I am now working on adding a third parameter to the function that would allow you to limit the results to a subset of properties. I'll update the issue once this is released as well.

@susannaanas Alright, this is now fully working. You can as of now say…
`WIKIDATAFACTS("Q42", "all", "P106")`
…to get all of Douglas Adams' occupations (i.e., `P106`). If you replace `"all"` with `"first"`, you will just get the first occupation. If you want several properties, pass them as an array like…
`WIKIDATAFACTS("Q42", "all", {"P31"; "P106"})`
See the new functionalities [in action](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1QuUVFl6x3c1Yj3J7jd_OTHYD2haVFVtebIw2It4KNoA/edit?usp=sharing).

I have just added a new function called `WIKIDATADESCRIPTIONS` ([live demo](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1xtj6H6H_4WcktqIpKpITGBeDE8jZQHyeEhgrv4PSfkQ/edit?usp=sharing)) that, as the name suggests, pulls in descriptions from Wikidata. For consistency reasons, I have further renamed the function `WIKIDATALABEL` (singular) to `WIKIDATALABELS` (plural). I thought this might be of interest for @susannaanas @fokky @Nautic.

@Nautic, what you are describing here is essentially the challenge of entity linking, _i.e._, going from an ambiguous string like "Jaguar" to the clearly and unambiguously defined thing [Jaguar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaguar), or, wait, rather [Jaguar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaguar_%28disambiguation%29)?! As you can see from this trivial example, the problem is hard, especially when there is no context. The Wikipedia Search API returns the most probable (list of) thing(s) for string, which is what I am exposing in the add-on. Everything else would be far beyond the scope of the objectives of the tool, which is why I hope you understand if I close the issue. Hope you still find the add-on useful!

Hi Tom, in the 'Jaguar' case: 
I suggest an additional disambiguation-index.

If the tool finds a disambiguation page, 
you could set the disambiguation-index to something like: 
x =' [Disambiguation Type I](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Begriffskl%C3%A4rung#Die_Begriffskl.C3.A4rungsseite_.28BKS.29)
y = [Disambiguation Type II](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Begriffskl%C3%A4rung#BKL_II_.E2.80.93_Das_Stichwort_f.C3.BChrt_auf_den_gel.C3.A4ufigsten_Sachartikel)
z = [Disambiguation Type III](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Begriffskl%C3%A4rung#BKL_III_.E2.80.93_Das_Stichwort_f.C3.BChrt_auf_eine_Weiterleitung)

So together with the reliability-index, the user would have a helpful information about 
the quality of each result :-)

Aim is to get a basis for an ABC-decision:
- which results can we use immediately
- which can we improve in an easy way by hand 
- which should we temporarily throw away 

Bests, Markus

Not yet, but I have not forgotten about it, no worries. What would help in order to have a holistic solution (and not just fix one particular function) would be if you could list all "namespace-able" functions here. Thanks.

Sure:
- WIKICATEGORYMEMBERS per above
- Not sure how WIKIARTICLESAROUND is calculated, but it might be worth limiting to namespaces (Say I wanted to figure out the relationships between policies on a particular wiki in the Wikipedia: Space, or I was interested in categories or templates). 
- WIKIINBOUNDLINKS, WIKIMUTUALLINKS, WIKIOUTBOUNDLINKS (specially, being able to distinguish between mainspace, and other kinds of spaces -- you may want to know if the article has been talked on in talk pages for instance, or is referenced in Wikipedia: space)
- WIKISEARCH -- probably can piggy back on MediaWiki's search by namespace features already there. For this one, you probably want a field that allows for multiple namespaces.

I think, of the existing tools, those are the only ones where you don't specifically query a title, so it would be worth being able to limit the outcomes.

Guys,

I've come across the same problem and thought I'd fire my findings up here.
The problem is with a bug in CF8 and CF9, I believe it has been fixed in CF9.1, but I haven't tested that yet.

The problem lies with the ArrayIsDefined() function which has a bug, resulting in an error when you pass it an index greater than the size of the array.
The quick fix is the change the conditional logic to to check for the length of the array as well.

I Updated the Apptacular\handlers\cfc\db\table.cfc and changed line 152 from 

if (ArrayIsDefined(columns, i+1)){

to

if (arrayLen(columns) gte i+1 and ArrayIsDefined(columns, i+1)){

and this fixes the error during code generation.

Hopefully this helps someone else.

Regards,
Odhran Hardy.

I've reproduced the issue on a clean project. This is what I've done:
1. create new CFBuilder project
2. create Apptacular Application
3. edit database model > change entity name on one of the tables
4. regenerate Application

Now the entity for witch you just changed the entity name has double properties.

I've had to change the entity name because the name of the column is "member" and this is a reserved word in ColdFusion ORM/Hibernate. I changed it to iMember (not because of Apple, the first letter of the name of the application is "i").

I've send you the schema in december per email, let me know if you want me to resend it.
I now also have the issue with tables for witch I didn't change the entity name...

    cargo build -p artifact-app
```

Sorry if that wasn't completely clear. I used to do this within `build.rs` but then things weren't working (IIRC they weren't working for windows for some reason).

Hi again! Happy to help. To give some insight into why that regex is there - Windows paths usually look like `X:\path\to\place`, where X is a drive letter. There are however variations. See this link for specific details: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/naming-a-file#maximum-path-length-limitation but basically, the way to ensure a path that might be too long for old windows API doesn't break stuff is to prefix it with `\\?\`, so you get something like `\\?\X:\path\to\place`. Programming languages usually then escape these slashes, so your string is `\\\\?\X:\\path\\to\\place`. This is all well and good - [except](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3591840/are-extended-length-paths-safe-to-use) that only some Windows API actually supports this extended syntax.

My regex workaround is to grab the string starting only from the first alphabetical character, i.e. the drive letter. This ensures that rust doesn't break trying to pass that to std::process::Command. Hope that makes sense.
Using cargo-web deploy before doing cargo-build like that worked successfully! I was able to fully compile the project :)

It USED to build+test and release artifact binaries for Linux, Mac and
Windows using Travis and Appveyor. It built on top of japaric's
trust <https://github.com/japaric/trust> template.

Basically none of this works anymore and you can feel complete freedom to
start from the ground up. I did some initial testing using *trust* and hit
a few issues, but that doesn't mean that isn't a valid path.

Some possible paths:

   - Use travis/appveyor's "happy path" for rust on multiple platforms
   <https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/multi-os/>. Basic unit tests worked a
   few weeks ago using the Linux image on Travis, that is probably a good
   place to start.
   - Use *trust* to do cross compiling:
   it uses it's own tools to set things up and I'm not sure it is really
   necessary anymore, but it is an option.
   - Use *Nix <https://nixos.org/nix/>*: this is kind of the direction I
   was planning but is highly complicated and not really mature. I don't
   recommend this path unless you are already a Nix aficionado.

T
he basic process is:

   - O
   pen a PR and Travis tests will run automatically.
   - Get unit tests working for all 3 platforms.
   - We'll do some test releases to try and get the process to release -- I
   think I'm the only person who can do this, but if you find you can as well
   that would be great

When things are going well I'll add you as a contributor so you can approve
PRs!

- Add `cargo-web` as a dependency.
- Update the `stdweb` version to `0.4.8` in `artifact-frontend`.
- Add `mdbook` as a dependency.

I'm unsure what you would like.

The "default" view is name+parts
```
# art ls                                                                                                                                                                              
|  | DONE TEST | NAME                    | PARTS                                                                                                                                                                  
|--|  83%  71% | REQ-data                | REQ-data-family, REQ-data-type, SPC-data
```

If you want just one of them, you specify it:
```
# art ls -L                                                                                                                                                                           
|  | DONE TEST | NAME                    | IMPLEMENTED  
```

When you pass the `-A` flag, additional flags disable columns. Interestingly, if you try to disable all of them it still displays `parts`, which is **definitely a bug**:

```
art ls -ADPOLT
|  | DONE TEST | NAME                    | PARTS   
|--|  83%  71% | REQ-data                | REQ-data-family, REQ-data-type, SPC-data
```

Do you mean you would like to ONLY display the name? I don't think that is currently supported (because of the above bug). I could add a
`-N` flag, but then I would have to support that *removing* the name when used with `-A`, which I suppose is fine (maybe someone might want to do that?).

So the reasons markdown was chosen are in #185. I should probably migrate those reasons to the design docs.

The reason I am not using toml is because yaml *renders* correctly in markdown. See that issue for more details.

Basically, to look even remotely good you would need something like:

    # REQ-foo
    ```
    partof = "REQ-bar"
    ```
    The above is the attributes, this is some text

Maybe I could recommend indenting... so this:

    # REQ-foo

        partof = [
            "REQ-bar",
            "REQ-baz",
        ]

    The above is the attributes, this is some text

This is a tough one, but the current behavior is intended.

The basic idea is that when you are designing a big feature its completion will be *completely determined by its subfeatures*. This is most obvious for `REQ`, since you literally *cannot* directly implement it.

However, I see your point. To aid in this, I am now implementing sublocations. So if you had a feature (`SPC-foo`) that had a large part as a separate spec (`SPC-foo-bar`) but also had two minor parts that were implemented directly in code (`SPC-foo.baz`, `SPC-foo.lab`), then those would show up as unimplemented if they were not implemented. You specify sublocations by just having `[[.baz]] [[.lab]]` anywhere in the text of your artifact, and then link with `#SPC-foo.baz`. See #186

Let me say, I'm not sure the best way to balance all these pieces and am open to feedback. I think the sublocations are going to be the best way to do so, but I really don't know. Part of me is unconcerned since the "completion status" piece of artifact is a pretty minor feature IMO. It's nice to have, but its not the main attraction.
(Being able to link code in the first place is the primary feature when it comes to "completion")
Also on the web-ui stuff -- if a bug isn't open feel free to do so.

Hmm, I like it. Probably needs some testing to see whether it can contain all features you have in the current format, but I don't see that as a problem.

I've changed the "end data" block from `---` to `###`. `###` doesn't get rendered at all in the end output, but is also a nice separator.

I'll keep experimenting, but I think this is the right approach.

One thing this breaks is that you won't be able to use a top header anywhere.

I.e. this will not be allowed:
```
# REQ-foo

# Some header for REQ-foo
```
It would be *possible* to support this, but honestly it would be cluttered. Note: this **IS** backwards compatible -- it would just mean that when a user tried to export to markdown it would throw an error (with a helpful message) and they would have to manually fix. Single headers would still be supported in toml.

@rubdos other than not supporting single headers, I don't see there being any issue. Between the `# REQ-name` and `###` there can exist *any arbitrary yaml*, so you can put literally anything there. Even better, `yaml` sees `#` as a comment, so it's not like `###` would have ever been parsed as real data anyway.

Speaking of yaml... I should think about maybe using a different format. I like the fact that yaml renders in markdown quite well though

```
- name1: value
- name2:
    - value1: 
        This is some really long text. This is some really long text.
        This is some really long text. This is some really long text.
        If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. 
    - value2: this is not as long
```

- name1: value
- name2:
    - value1: 
        This is some really long text. This is some really long text.
        This is some really long text. This is some really long text.
        If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. If I write a very long line it gets wrapped nicely. 
    - value2: this is not as long

## Hmm
I actually think github might render comments slightly different than `.md` files. I expected the text block to be merged (without newlines).

On the other hand, maybe sticking with toml is the way to go. The stuff between `# REQ-foo` and `###` *is actually data*, it's probably good for it to look like data!

<details>

# REQ-foo
partof = [
    "REQ-foo",
    "REQ-bar",
    "REQ-baz",
]
done = "this is done"
###
Here is some text
</details>

Hmm... I don't like that though, especially that the indents are deleted.

my two cents:
I like reStructuredText better, but markdown is more common.
I'm not sure if I'd describe markdown as trivially parseable, is there no crate for that?

toml isn't very pretty, and does not have many features, but it's easy to maintain and easy to parse.
md is pretty, but: there are several dialects and extensions around (eg. [man 5 pandoc_markdown](https://linux.die.net/man/5/pandoc_markdown)) and AFAIR allows to litter HTML throughout the whole document.

I'd vote to implement a very small and restrictive subset of md, to keep it maintainable. 
Maybe allow for an external parser to generate html, that can be fed back into the system.

I have quite a bit of negative feelings against reStructuredText. Markdown has it's faults, but reStructuredText has way too much syntax for my taste... it's not very "clean".

Interestingly, I actually like the fact that you can insert `html` in markdown -- it is a feature I use in the web-ui to great effect.

Also, I'm not suggesting I parse the markdown exactly... the basic design would be two regexes:

- The header line is (approximately):
```
#\s(REQ|TST|SPC)-\w+\s*
```

I would then pull lines into a buffer until I hit one of:
- the "end of attributes" line
```
###+\s*
```
- another header line
- the end of the file

If I hit another header line, the buffer==`text`. If I hit the "end of attributes" line then I parse until a header line and that is my text.

The parsed attributes would be desrialized using a yaml library, so I wouldn't have to do much there.

Re-writing the files would be almost as easy. I don't see a lot of technical risk here.

I'm not sure I follow. Let me make sure I understand your proposal. As I see it there are two of them:

## Feature1: add the ability to add "tags"
This is something I would use #107 for. One of the design requirements of artifact is that it is very slow to add features and I am basically unwilling to add additional attributes at all (but would allow a plugin to do so).

## Feature 2: use pijul to track progress
I'm a little confused about the implementation here. I'm not sure why Pijul could provide any kind of automated way of detecting that a requirement changed (other than the way other version control systems already do). Also, I am unwilling to tie artifact to any *particular* vcs system

Related: I have another design I've been throwing around that I've been thinking could help address this. It would allow you to define "mini specifications" *inside* the text block of SPC or TST types that can link to source code. So you could do something like this:

```
[SPC-foo]
text = '''
This has multiple parts of implementation:
- [[.input]]: take the input
- [[.process]]: process the input
- [[.log]] log the result
'''
```

Each of these "sub-parts" could then be linked in code using `#SPC-foo.input`, `#SPC-foo.process`, etc. Since the `.` character is currently illegal, there is no possibility of overlap.

The sub-parts would then be used for also calculating the completeness of the item.

In the web-ui, you would be able to click to the line of code that the linked items are at.

This would also be useful when combined with #158, as you could create a graph that also links to code.

**Related**: the spec in [SPC-artifact](https://vitiral.github.io/artifact/#artifacts/spc-artifact) needs to be updated to reflect the new design. Somehow I forgot to do that. There should probably be a `REQ-completed` to reflect this dicussion.

The original logic was to have `#SPC-foo` mark anything as 100% done all the time. That was annoying, because you often want to link to parent items in code, as well as their children.

In the end, I settled on either the `done=` field or a link in code being the equivalent of a "done child". Note that if you *do mark the children as done* (either in code or with `done=`), then you don't need to mark the parent as done -- which is the behavior you want in the end.

This gives you an idea that:
- The parent is implemented somewhere in code
- Its children are not

This leads to being 50% done for a single child parent (which in my experience is unusual), to 33% done with two children, 25% with three children, etc -- and is a reasonably good description of the completion status of the item.

I would love to know more about your thinking. We can put these thoughts into the new SPC/REQ, which probably needs to be written to elaborate this more.

I can see how marking the parent as partially complete could be handier than other solutions. But it is more surprising and inconsistent too. What I did not get from your reply.. why is it not okay to mark the parent as 0 % done when all its children are 0 % done?

So I'm thinking one solution for this might be to just *ignore* the code-link/done-field if the item has any children. That would *allow you to link* but would also make it simply equal to the average of it's children.

I think there might be an even better solution here, which is the [DOT graph description language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOT_(graph_description_language))

It has extremely concise syntax and can be rendered as a imagemap (image where nodes can provide links).

Use graphiz to allow more programmatic trees, including links within nodes:
- http://www.graphviz.org/content/output-formats#dimap
- link support using imagemaps: http://www.graphviz.org/content/graphviz-links-within-record-nodes
- http://viz-js.com/ : this is probably the javascript library I would use to render things
    - if you replace the `a1` line with the following, you can get links to work in the SVG format: 
    - `{"[[REQ-foo]]" [fontcolor=blue; URL="https://google.com";]} -> b3;`
- attributes are well documented here: http://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/attrs.html#d:URL

You can "declare" node attributes like this. Further attributes can still be defined at later points.

```
    {"REQ-foo" [fontcolor=blue;URL="https://google.com";]};
    {"b0" [fontcolor=blue; URL="https://google.com";]};
    {"b1" [fontcolor=red; URL="http://xkcd.com"];};
```

While I do like the graphviz system, I have strong feelings about it. The dot language is an ambiguous mess and the documentation is horrible. Took me two days to figure out what will work and what won't: otherwise dot is concise and versatile.

The documentation is pretty bad, but I'm curious what you mean by
"ambiguous mess"? Can you give some examples?

**Edit:**

I'm also curious if you have thoughts for an alternative? I'm all ears!

For my use case, I thought it was quite succinct and NOT ambiguous:

- nodes are just plain text `node`, a string `"a node"` or if you want to add attributes, a `{...}` block `{"a node" [URL="https://google.com"]}`
- nodes can be connected with `->`
- you can use the same name multiple times:

```
a -> b -> c
a -> c -> d -> e -> f
```

Also there is *some* way to specify if statements, but I can't find it right now...

Okay, it's not *great* ... haha

Here are some pretty decent tutorials I have come across:

- basic tutorial: http://www.graphviz.org/pdf/dotguide.pdf
- pretty good examples and references: http://graphs.grevian.org/documentation
- more good examples: http://tonyballantyne.com/graphs.html

As for if statements... just use the [diamond shape](http://www.graphviz.org/doc/info/shapes.html).

I'm looking online for alternatives and really don't see any -- it looks pretty spiffy to me honestly.

Alternatives: none.
It's the best tool for the job, I just wanted to sound the warning.
At first glance, dot seems elegant and simple; until you try to get it to behave the way you want.
One of the most offputting features: I wanted my subgraph in a box.
So, try to find the attribute in the [official documents](http://www.graphviz.org/content/attrs), the way they do their documentation is not my thing. Explanation and vaild scope are just too far away from each other.

At some time you give up and try to work [by example](http://www.graphviz.org/content/cluster). After bisection you realize nothing you did is different but you still won't get a box around the subgraph.
Once you realize, that you get a box around it, just by giving the subgraph a different name (e.g. cluster_0): that's why I think is ambiguous.
If you just want to output arbitrary dependency graphs, dot is just fine.

We took the approach of providing tutorials, a collection of examples with corresponding "recipes" and in-depth descriptions of the language, attributes, node shapes, etc. Clusters are described in the dot tutorial, several examples are given on the Gallery page, and clusters and their semantics are described in the dot language page. The tutorial notes _A cluster is a subgraph placed in its own distinct rectangle of the layout. A subgraph is recognized as a cluster when its name has the prefix cluster._ The Gallery example labeled Cluster has the text _This small example illustrates dot's feature to draw nodes and edges in clusters or separate rectangular layout regions. Clusters are encoded as subgraphs whose names have the prefix 'cluster'._  Subgraphs and clusters relate to the graph's topology; they are not layout or rendering attributes. In any case, this hardly warrants the language being viewed as an ambiguous mess. The language is very concise and there is no ambiguity in any well-formed graph described in dot.

I've decided to ALWAYS allow this feature for writing artifacts, but when formatting it will always be formatted to the full form.

So the following will be valid and will always result in a single list of strings (except when there is only one item, that will remain a single string)
```
[REQ-foo]
partof = "REQ-single"  # this will not change

[REQ-bar]
partof = "REQ-[foo, bar]" 
# becomes:
# partof = [
#     "REQ-foo",
#     "REQ-bar",
# ]

[REQ-baz]
# this is the "standard" format and doesn't change
partof = [
    "REQ-foo",
    "REQ-bar",
]

[REQ-faz]
partof = ["REQ-foo", "REQ-bar-[1,2]"]
# becomes:
# partof = [
#     "REQ-foo",
#     "REQ-bar-1",
#     "REQ-bar-2",
# ]
```

So, you should do a rebase, not a merge. Can you do the following:

```
git checkout --hard 6a8747c
git push origin server-inprogress -f
git checkout --hard e3c8aba
git fetch
git rebase origin/server-inprogress
git push origin server-inprogress
```

That will delete any local work, so make sure to stash it or save it some other way.

The normal workflow for pulling down changes would be:
```
git fetch
git rebase origin/server-inprogress
```
then you can push your own local changes.

Similarily, when pulling changes from master it is just:
```
git fetch
git rebase origin/master
```

Some thoughts:
- I like the idea of extra attributes through `settings.toml`. I had previously thought about using an `extra` parameter directly on the artifact which was arbitrarily json but this is much better. I'm thinking of the format and I'm thinking something like:
```
[attrs]
# you must specify the type, these are optional and have no constraints (besides type)
unchecked-int = "int"
unchecked-str = "string"

[attrs.checked-int]
type = "int"
min = 0
max = 10
required = true

[attrs.optional-checked-str]
type = "str"
max = 10  # max refers to the length
```
- for querying, I think you would need to use something like [jsonpath](https://github.com/dchester/jsonpath). This would be through a flag in the cmdline and an option in the web-ui
- for web-ui probably would just display these below partof/parts. For `ls` command there would probably be an `--attrs` method where you could spell out the attributes to list.

Other reasons this would be nice:
- I would like to support plugins in the future. Some of these plugins would probably want to have custom attributes.

Yet another reason this would be nice: if you ever decide that end-users can add custom top level artifacts (e.g. US for user story, which is one I'd like to have), users can fully customize them.

And an even better reason: you could now define your `RSK` attributes through a "default" set of attributes, instead of hard coding them. I think that would be very nice.

Negative: adds complexity to the user that I think is rarely needed which might confuse people. Complexity is always something which should be avoided as much as possible. 

For instance, user stories should just be part of the `text` in requirements. I don't see any benefit of creating a separate field for them. Actually I don't see any benefits outside of the RSK artifacts. Can anyone come up with other examples?

@vitiral Providing a way to specify attributes across all ART would make artifact way more powerful. But, as you, I fear the added complexity in code, usability and configuration will divert attention from the original goal of artifact (*simple* quality), which I'd rather not sacrifice.

As @rubdos, I have thought about (mis?)-using it for checking and enforcing attributes, to define structure on i.e. scenarios (or user-stories), stakeholders (needs, roles, goals, ...) and possibly other artifacts.

(kinda off-topic) My "solution" until now: 
- Write a REQ that you want to document something (identify stakeholders).
- Add the SPC which defines attributes you want to capture (role, goal, needs, representative, ...).
- Document these somewhere else (we use LaTeX) and mark that as the implementation of the spec.

Downsides to this approach:
- definitions are outside artifact and must be enforced through other means (as with all implementations).
- if you derive requirements from these, they will not be traceable in artifact.

@vitiral I came up with another attribute outside of RSK:
priority of a REQ to balance them against each other.

And another for requirements: 
type: [(non-)functional, performance, usability, constraint, ...]

I've decided to go forward with this feature, soley for plugin support and ISO support. I like this because it doesn't increase the complexity of the "standard" product, but allows plugins or users to make things as complex as THEY want to.

We already indirectly depend on `unicode-length` and `unicode-segmentation`, so it shouldn't be any trouble to add direct dependencies on them. I propose that if the string doesn't fit into the required width, then we iterate over the grapheme clusters until we reach the maximum appropriate unicode string width, then insert an ellipsis.

If we want to get fancy with ellipsis:
* If the string is all ASCII/Latin-1/etc then we shouldn't assume capabilities of the terminal and insert a 3 character pseudo-ellipsis `...`.
* If the string has fancy Unicode characters, then it should be safe to use more Unicode and insert a real ellipsis character `…`, thus letting us include two more characters of the original string.
This might be unneeded complexity though.

I'm also curious if we want to split lines on `\n` or if we want to follow the [Unicode Newline Guidelines](http://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode4.0.0/ch05.pdf#G10213) for splitting lines.
@vitiral any opinions on these questions?

I think don't do any fancy elipses, but it should support unicode width. 

I don't know what the unicode newline Guide is (not going to read it now) but imo just use /n

**Text that misbehaves:**
```
This is going to misbehave.
Because the text is immediately after the topic.
```
**Text that behaves:**
```
This one will work.

The body text is separate from the topic.
```

I also think this is made worse by the fact that Markdown is aware of lists and such, but the line breaking code is not, and you're putting your lists directly against the first line like
```
The subject is here.
1. This
2. List
3. Is
4. Attached
```

I think it is fine to just grab the first line (not markdown line -- but text until the first `\n`).

When someone is running `art ls` with `-T` they don't want all the information (otherwise they would use `-l` as well) -- they just want the summary. That summary should fit in the first line.

I think truncating it to 50 characters as well would be a good idea -- which is far less than the 80 characters allowed, so I think we should be good :)
thanks for doing this btw, and sorry for other bugs to be popping up!
