First, to clear up confusion, artifact links *specifications and/or tests* to source code, not requirements.

I'm fairly confused about your use case. Let me try and re-summarize and you can tell me where I am wrong:
1. you want to write your design specification
2. you want your design spec to link to your source code impelmentation (and documentation)
3. However, you want to use this to track the completion of your *documentation*, not the completion of your code.

Is that correct?

The main purpose of artifact is to write design docs and track where they are implemented (while also making code self documenting). You can feel free to define "implemented" as "implemented and documented" if you want. In that case, just don't comlete the link.

If you want to have a bunch of "TODO" completion points, you can just *not* link like this:

```
TODO: SPC-my-doc
```

Instead of
```
see: #SPC-my-doc
```

Then when you have finished the document you just add the missing `#`.

Does that help?

Thanks for your reply. See my reply below

Den 28/02/2017 12.38 AM skrev "Garrett Berg" <notifications@github.com>:

> First, to clear up confusion, artifact links *specifications and/or tests to source code, not requirements.

> I'm fairly confused about your use case. Let me try and re-summarize and you can tell me where I am wrong:
>1. you want to write your design specification
>2. you want your design spec to link to your source code impelmentation (and documentation)
>3. However, you want to use this to track the completion of your *documentation*, not the completion of your code.

> Is that correct?

Yes!
And this leads to some questions:

1. How do I track the completion of my documentation? (to which you have suggested an answer, down below)

2. can *all* kinds of documentation relating to code reasonably be
shoehorned into the form of a specification? In my mind, specifications deals with all the interfaces that code presents, and there might be other aspects of code behaviour that one would also like to link to specific parts of the source code (such as algorithm design considerations, algorithm mechanics, program control flow (eg. 'this part of the code does the instantiations of all the constructors'))

3. Could it be a good idea to treat documentation (any doc that goes beyond requirements specification) as source code in itself? Thus using Artifact to track the completion of this documentation, just as it tracks real source code? This could perhaps be neat for my use case, but perhaps also for others. I see that the Artifact project has a wiki that documents all the doc aspects that goes beyond mere requirements specification. But how complete is this Wiki? Are there known requirements for the wikis content that hasn't yet been fulfilled? Could Artifact be used to track these
questions?

Further on, I guess some parts of the Wiki is tightly associated to
specific parts of the source code (or at least we could imagine this to be the case). Could Artifact be expanded to also track to which extend documentation (documentation that goes beyond specification) has documented specific 'documentation craving' parts of the source code?

> The main purpose of artifact is to write design docs and track where they are implemented (while also making code self documenting).

How does it become self documenting? By shoehorning all documentation aspects into the form of a specification?

> If you want to have a bunch of "TODO" completion points, you can just *not* link like this:

> `SPC-my-doc`

> Instead of

> `#SPC-my-doc`

> Then when you have finished the document you just add the missing #.

> Does that help?


Yes this will help, but it doesn't exactly give me full on documentation requirements fulfillment tracking.

My desired workflow would be something like this:

I write down requirements for my documentation (high level categories that I want my documentation to cover). Whenever I work on my source code, and I spot a component (function/module/constructor/etc.) that really needs documentation, I tag it with the relevant documentation requirement tag (and also the functions
name).

Then I go write some documentation and tag it as documenting component X. Then Artifact can tell me that, for requirement Q, I have documented component X, but I'm still missing to document the components Y and Z. Thus Artifact tracks to which extent I have actually written the documentation that I have required of myself.

But maybe it's just be. Maybe I should just get into the habit of phrasing all my documentation as a design specification. And live without full on tracking of my documentation progress.

Thanks for your time :)

> 1. How do I track the completion of my documentation? (to which you have suggested an answer, down below)

I would like to point out that while artifact **does** track completion that is mostly for convienience. If you want to track "task/story/epic" completion I would use an agile tool Zenhub or just github issues

Maybe I will eventually make a task/story/epic tracking tool... but artifact is not it.

It sounds like most of what you want to do would be better done with task tracking tools and some source code `#DOCME` tags.

The primary purpose of artifact is once you *have* documented your code anyone reading your code can see which specification it implements (the `#SPC-my-spec` will be right there in the doc string). Then they can read your design docs to get an idea how everything fits toghther (and see where everything is implemented in source code)

> there might be other aspects of code behaviour that one would also like to link to specific parts of the source code (such as algorithm design considerations, algorithm mechanics, program control flow (eg. 'this part of the code does the instantiations of all the constructors'))

This is why you can do this:

```
[SPC-function]
text = '''
function does awesome stuff and uses:
- [[SPC-function-algorithm1]] to do awesome stuff 1
- [[SPC-function-algorithm2]] to do awesome stuff 2
'''

[SPC-function-algorithm1]
text = '''
algorithm that is awesome
'''

[SPC-function-algorithm2]
text = '''
another algorithm that is awesome
'''
```

The `[[...]]` notation was just released in version 0.6.2

So the [[...]] notation is equivalent to the 'partof' notation used when
defining requirements?

No, it doesn't do anything but help with documentation. When you render it it the web-ui it creates a link.

Think of it as a "reference". You might say "this is related to this other requirement".

Note that `SPC-function-algorithm1` is automatically partof `SPC-function` because `SPC-function` is a prefix (parent) by name.

Both of those sound good, though it might be useful to be able to specify a specific percentage, for cases where estimation is necessary.

Another use case: if people want to use artifact for large, existing codebases, the prospect of retroactively tracking down everywhere these tags go could be daunting. 

ya, it would be nice to be able to say "done='TODO'" when you are first using the tool.

That brings up an interesting point, where if you specify it is "done" AND have a link that I should raise an error in the check command.

@dead10ck I put a lot of thought into doing just that and purposefully decided against it.

What it comes down is the question "what is this tool for?" This is a tool for writing design docs and linking to implementation. The "% done" is to just help you get a general idea of whether it is implemented or not, not be for feature tracking.

There are tons of quality issue/task/story/epic tracking tools out there, and this is a fundamentally different space. Trying to update a value *in a text file* that has a percentage would be tedious and create too many commits in your revision history. I opted for "done" to be a binary value.

I would love feedback, but that is the reasoning. I should probably put this in some kind of FAQ on the wiki

For anyone else with this problem:
I used mann-ed's answer [here](https://github.com/diesel-rs/diesel/issues/321#issuecomment-218332202)

I started with `sudo updatedb && sudo locate libpq` which gave a few results. I found `usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpq.so.5` which was quite similar to the path in the link ( `/usr/pgsql-9.3/lib/libpq.so.5` ).

I then created a symlink to /usr/lib/libpq.so (where diesel expects this library) using 
'sudo ln -s /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpq.so.5 /usr/lib/libpq.so`

Then I was able to successfully install diesel with `cargo install diesel_cli --force --no-default-features --features 'postgres'

(I used `--force` because I accidentally installed diesel without the postgres feature, and needed `--force` to overwrite the install. It shouldn't be necessary for a clean install)

Thanks!

- There is no help, alas – clippy works as a rustc plugin, and there is no interface to inject help text. The site has all the documentation, though
- clippy doesn't fix anything by itself. To do this reliably is quite hard. I hear killercup has a rustfix tool in early development that should be able to apply suggestions from lints, and the IntelliJ-Rust plugin also has made advances on that front.

@ your question: i had the same one about bin and lib, and found the answer by @shepmaster [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/26953326/247482):

> ``` console
> $ tree
> .
> ├── Cargo.toml
> └── src
>     ├── bin
>     │   └── mybin.rs
>     └── lib.rs
> 
> $ cat Cargo.toml
> [package]
> name = "mylib"
> version = "0.0.1"
> authors = ["me <me@gmail.com>"]
> ```
> 
> Additionally, you can just create a src/main.rs that will be used as the defacto executable. Unfortunately, this conflicts with the cargo doc command:
> 
> > Cannot document a package where a library and a binary have the same name. Consider renaming one or marking the target as doc = false

The behavior I was going to do was display the path from the `{repo}` folder (same folder `.rsk` folder is in).

I think the correct route here is to have two behaviors:
- if `-l` is specified (long form), display the `git path`
- otherwise, display only the file name.

Does that make sense? Or should the `git path` always be displayed? I am torn.

I think always displaying the `git path` is the best option because
1. We are already used to this behaviour with git
2. The user may have multiple files with the same name. So having this `git path` avoids conflicts and user mistakes. For example, I see that for `rsk` itself you have several `settings.rsk` files: at `reqs/settings.rsk` and at `reqs/core/settings.rsk`
3. If the user follows the best practices of your tutorial, the path from `{repo}` should not be very long. At least, `git path` will always be shorter than the whole path so it's always better.

Just to be sure we understand each other, what you mean by `git path` is 

```
reqs/purpose.rsk 
```

where `reqs` is child of `{repo}`
And we agree that this is much more clearer than

```
/home/username/some/long/path/{repo}/reqs/purpose.rsk 
```

I think you are right: always display the git path.

`git path` means a little more -- it is the relative path _from the cwd_

so if I am in the `reqs/cmd` folder of rsk, and I have changed `src/cmd/ls.rs`, then the gitpath there will be:

```
../../src/cmd/ls.rs
```
Yes you are right for the relative path. I think we are okay for how to implement file path!
Sounds good. Something I realized is that the repo is irrelevant -  all git does is relative path. Should be fairly simple
Oh you're right, it's simply a relative path. Nice

I'd like to rename some of these in order to get some consistency in how they read. Also this would make implementing handlers look cleaner. Basically `/api/foo/` should do one thing, not different things based on what comes next.

1. `/api/draft/:id` looks good. I imagine you want this to be filtered based on what the requesting user is allowed to see. For example, a spectator will get the full replay, but a drafter in an ongoing draft will only get the history of the draft that they would have seen. (Needs #31 to be fixed.)
2. `/api/user/:id/drafts` -> `/api/alldrafts`. I'm not convinced there's a use case for a user would asking about what drafts are available on behalf of another user, so specifying a user id is unnecessary. I can be talked into `/api/draftlist` or `/api/drafts` or something similar.
3. `/api/draft/:draftId/user/:userId/picks`. Why do we need this at all? Is this just a subset of `/api/draft/:id`?
4. `/api/draft/:draftId/user/:userId/pickCard` -> `/api/pick`. I'll start passing card ids to the client in `/api/draft/:id` and you can just send me the card id to be picked. The draft id can be derived from the pick id. This is how picks currently work anyway.

I don't think the server cares about any of the card properties. The client wants the data. I think we can reduce the `cards` table in the db from this:
```
CREATE TABLE cards(
  id integer primary key autoincrement,
  pack number,
  edition text,
  number text,
  tags text,
  name text,
  faceup number default false,
  original_pack number,
  modified number default 0,
  mtgo string,
  cmc number,
  type string,
  color string);
```
to this:
```
CREATE TABLE cards(
  id integer primary key autoincrement,
  pack number,
  original_pack number,
  card_info text);
```
where `card_info` is a JSON blob we blindly pass to the client.

For standard drafts, the draft creation script will need to know some of that data:
- power level rating
- color
- color identity
- rarity

I can imagine that list expanding if we need more data for heuristics, like we would need to know card types to detect Legendary Creature cards for the Legendary Creature card slot in DOM drafts.

The Scryfall JSON blob that their API returns is quite large and contains a lot of data we don't care about and will never care about. Similarly, we need to add additional fields like power level rating to our JSON. We should decide if we're going to use their JSON format but delete fields we don't want or if we're going to go with our own format. The former is probably easier.
low priority, as this would be most useful for IRL drafts where we're opening physical packs and playing with them.

R&D apparently lays out sheets by hand to balance for card strength in addition to color. We can use LSV's set reviews to get relative ratings for the cards and do this as well. This should help simulate a real draft environment considerably.

player A has 2 packs, the first containing 2 cards and the second containing 1 card. player A picks one from the first pack, passing the now-1-card-pack to player B. The system auto-picks the last card for player A from their second pack, but player B's new pack is never auto-picked from.

To clarify how the draft spectators channel creation should work:

1. draft fills
2. draft-spectators-n is created in the "spectators" category
3. topic is set to the replay link
4. all members are permitted except drafters
5. draft finishes
6. all members are allowed in
7. draft games finish
8. wait some amount of time (3 days?)
9. lock channel and move to archived category

The condition expression evaluation seems to be the curse.
But, the compiler shouldn't distinguish `type specifier` to `identifier` when it is doing preprocessing, right? So `long` of `(long)1.2` should be treated as an `identifier`, and the standard says: an `identifier` in condition expression of control directive after expansion should be treated as `0`, which results in this problem here.

gcc gets right, but I doubt if it's standard, here I found the specifications in C11 standard [6.10.1.4] :
> After all replacements due to macro expansion and the defined unary
operator have been performed, all remaining identifiers (including those lexically
identical to keywords) are replaced with the pp-number 0, and then each preprocessing
token is converted into a token.
NO. Even if you replace `long` as 0, the compiler should generate an error after `1.2`.

The problem here is not whether the compiler distinguishes `type specifier` or not, nor whether it replaces `identifier` as 0, but the compiler should generate an error or waring to the user: there are extra tokens or invalid tokens remaining.

Why "no"? The error reporting can be done by detecting the end of this directive line after parsing one expression. Should (long) be treated (0) ?

https://wiki.ubuntu.com/SecurityTeam/PIE
gcc 6.2.0 turns on -pie by default, which means it always trying to generate **_Position Independent Executable_** file when **_-no-pie_** is not explicitly specified.  But wgtcc doesn't support PIE/PIC.
So, the solution is, replace line 44 of **_Makefile_** with **_./$(OBJS_DIR)$(TARGET) -no-pie $$test; \\_**

I doubt if both are correct, it is just that the preprocessor's dump function can't generate pretty readable code.
The preprocessor must handle macro expansion carefully in order to get right column number etc. It's tricky. That explains why early C compilers don't contain column number in diagnostic messages.
I think they are not identical token stream. `+ +` means two separate `+` tokens to lexer, and `++` means `increment operator` to lexer.

That right way of checking if the compiler handles column(or space) correctly is try below snippet:
```
#define PLUS +
#define EMPTY
#define f(x) =x=
#define STRINGIZE(x) #x
#define TEST(x) STRINGIZE(x)
const char* str = TEST(+PLUS -EMPTY- PLUS+ f(=));
```
__str__ should be initiated by string literal __"++ -- ++ ==="__ which are both generated by wgtcc and gcc.
It's just one of numerous test cases.

The -E option is just for dumping the preprocessed code for programmer. wgtcc 's dump function is so simple that the dumped code can't be compiled to get the same by compiling the .c file. But it can be fixed by simply inserting a space between two tokens.

Actually, `-E` option may be used by other compilers. That's why the output must contain the line number information. In early days, the preprocessor runs as a separate pass. Of course, if you don't want your preprocessor to be a stand alone one, that's right.

So it is the dump function that should be fixed.

https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/cpp/Wrapper-Headers.html

> This directive works like ‘#include’ except in searching for the specified file: it starts searching the list of header file directories after the directory in which the current file was found.

假设现在有3个同名的头文件math.h, 它们被找到的顺序是：
1. /foo/math.h
2. /bar/math.h
3. /hello/math.h

现在/bar/math.h这个文件，如果想包含/hello/math.h,那么他只要写:

``` c
#include_next "math.h"
```

按照你的理解， 这会导致这个预处理器找到/bar/math.h(第一个找到的是/foo/math.h), 于是无限循环。

题外话， 这三个头文件被搜索到的顺序，隐含的意义是：/foo/math.h 应当是/bar/math.h 的某种扩充或修正， /bar/math.h 则是/hello/math.h的扩充。这种情况下，应该总是/foo/math.h include_next "math.h" 去把/bar/math.h 包含进来，而/bar/math.h 同样用include_next 去把/hello/math.h 包含进来。这样.c文件就只需要简单的include "math.h" 了。

cpp.cc代码中的continue，就是为了跳过/foo/math.h，直到找到/bar/math.h(也就是自身) :)
希望你理解了～～

当然，SearchFile()这样简单的reverse头文件目录的搜索顺序是不对的。应该仅仅是调整库头文件目录和用户头文件目录之间的顺序。。。

如果你在foo.c 里面写：

``` c
#include_next "math.h"
```

用gcc编译，它会给你warning：

``` c
gcc -std=c11 -Wall -I./foo -I./bar foo.c
warning: #include_next in primary source file
 #include_next "math.h"
```

而事实上，如果gcc此时干的事情是将foo.c中的include_next， 直接换成了include，你可以加一个 -E 看一下预处理后的结果。可能写foo.c 的人想要包含的是/bar/math.h 结果gcc给了他/foo/math.h。gcc尽最大能力让程序编译通过了，但是结果"出人意料"。wgtcc干脆就不给warning了，强制只能在math.h 里面include_next math.h(这也是include_next设计的初衷)。

理解了。

原来 https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/cpp/Wrapper-Headers.html

> This directive works like ‘#include’ except in searching for the specified file: it starts searching the list of 
> header file directories after the directory in which the current file was found.

这一段讲的就是gcc中对include_next的实现方法。

我追踪了gcc的源码，发现最终在 https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/blob/4d2a90e08fd5a0ee89a0177c9179df2fa984ff28/libcpp/files.c 中的search_path_head函数中就是这样处理的：

```
if (type == IT_INCLUDE_NEXT && file->dir && file->dir != &pfile->no_search_path)
    dir = file->dir->next;
```
难得你看的这么认真^_^

The segment error is cause by pop_back() a token list that has size 1, so the first element would be erased. But i forgot to update the begin_ member, result in begin_ still points to a freed list node. Then segment fault.

There is still a bug: during macro substitution, when we insert the replacement Tokens back to the begin of the token sequence, if there is a preceding NEW_LINE token, then the begin token will never be "the begin of line"(but it used to be). It results in a situation that we couldn't detect a preprocessing instruction if it immediately follows a macro substitution.
The macro substitution has been fixed by detecting the preceding NEW_LINE token when insert back to the begin of the token sequence.

To reproduce this issue, you will need to test using the feature implemented by https://github.com/ymotongpoo/vsc-licenser/pull/65 , and select Custom license header.

Steps to reproduce:
Sample project for testing:
[licenser_test.zip](https://github.com/ymotongpoo/vsc-licenser/files/5525192/licenser_test.zip)

1. Prepare a few shell scripts with shebang in the first line, like these ones
test.sh
```
#! /usr/bin/bash
echo "This is a test script"
```
and test2.sh,
```
#! /usr/bin/bash
echo "This is another test script"
```
Put these two files under a folder named scripts.

2. Prepare a .vscode/settings.json like this under the workspace:
```
{
    "licenser.projectName": "Test Project",
    "licenser.license": "Custom",
    "licenser.customHeader": "\n@PROJECT@\nFile Name: @FILE@\nCopyright @YEAR@ Do whatever you want with this one."
}
```

3. Open this folder with VS Code, open script/test.sh, then right click script folder, then click "lincenser: Insert license headers to content",

The correct output should be:
test.sh
```
#! /usr/bin/bash
# 
# Test Project
# File Name: test.sh
# Copyright 2020 Do whatever you want with this one.
# 

echo "This is a test script"

```
test2.sh
```
#! /usr/bin/bash
# 
# Test Project
# File Name: test2.sh
# Copyright 2020 Do whatever you want with this one.
# 

echo "This is another test script"

```

However, with current solution, the output would be:
test.sh
```
# 
# Test Project
# File Name: test.sh
# Copyright 2020 Do whatever you want with this one.
# 

#! /usr/bin/bash
echo "This is a test script"

```
test2.sh
```
# 
# Test Project
# File Name: test.sh
# Copyright 2020 Do whatever you want with this one.
# 

#! /usr/bin/bash
echo "This is another test script"

```

And if header is inserted from command palette, the output matches the correct ones.

Hey, sorry for the delayed response. Unfortunately, I decided not to accept this pull request with the following reasons.
1. GPL2+/GPL3+ is not well-known way to describe the use cases which you suggest.
2. I couldn't find many cases where 'or later' clause is not specified.
3. Now we have custom license header option and this feature covers the use case that you need to have.

Sure, that's fine. Thanks for considering this.
Regardless, I'd still like to reply to your remarks.

1. https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Licensing:Main uses GPLv3+ etc, and https://spdx.org/licenses/ also lists them (although as deprecated now and with - instead of v. I went with "v" because of Fedora's table and the fact that you have that right now).

2. The Linux Kernel, Git (GPLv2), Privacy Badger (GPLv3), are among projects that have opted for the "single version" GPL.

The one you pointing at is the guide for the source code under ASF, which seems not applied to general repos with Apache License 2.0. If you have more info on the generic guideline, please share the link to it.

@dlech hi there! This is first time to get this kind of concrete set of pull request to achieve working functionality!! I really appreciate your contribution! I reviewed the commit and it sounds reasonable. I accept this request.
it's not valid use of LICENSE file. Do you find any OSS that allow the projects to use license header as license description? Please reopen the issue and give me some examples if you find any.

Maybe what I describe is not very accurate.

The currently behavior is:

1. create the `LICENSE` file in root folder.
1. create license header in other files, like `README.md`.

expected behavior:

1. create the `LICENSE` file in root folder.
1. **DO NOT** create license header in other files.

Do you come up with names of exceptional filenames, such as `README.md`, `COPYING` and so on? At least, I'll force embedding license headers for source files in this extension, but I agree for those exceptions.

You should not force embedding license headers for source files because some source files do not use `//` as comment, like python.
Also, when the source script run on linux, the first line must be `#!/usr/bin/env *`.

> You should not force embedding license headers for source files because some source files do not use // as comment, like python.

As far as I read your comment, this is not a feature request but a bug, because this extension changes the comment notation based on the file extension. For instance, `#` should be selected as comment notation for Python source files as written in the [notation.ts](https://github.com/ymotongpoo/vsc-licenser/blob/develop/src/notation.ts#L85)

 > Also, when the source script run on linux, the first line must be #!/usr/bin/env *

This is also a bug if the license header is not skipping first line when there is shebang. (the process for it is done [here](https://github.com/ymotongpoo/vsc-licenser/blob/develop/src/extension.ts#L184))

So can you raise bugs for respective symptoms if you see the unintended behavior with latest version.
Not everyone needs the license headers break destroy their custom headers.

> Not everyone needs the license headers break destroy their custom headers.

Then can you give me examples for the "custom headers"? Otherwise the ideas for the options to exclude files where the auto insertion of the default license header should be avoided? Current behavior is usual on IDEs or many other plugins for other editors.

Though you mention "everyone", I just got the comments only from "you" and I'd love to accept constructive opinions to improve this extensions rather than complains. Otherwise you can send me a patch for your expected behavior. This is personal OSS project and I'm building this as my hobby.
